p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report

Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I rise to speak as the new Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions for the 47th Parliament. I present the first report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following petitions:
Parliamentary Standards

It is blatantly clear to many Australian's there is a broad and increasing issue relating to the lack of accountability, transparency and public disclosure coming from government members. The lack of accountability, transparency and relevant public disclosure is clearly allowing opportunities for some members to overtly withhold their true alliances, agendas and agreements.

We therefore ask the House to develop and install a Parliamentary Accountability, Transparency and Disclosures Act. The following proposed requirements will be within the act which will apply to all parliamentary members:
Declare any share or ownership of all private or family companies, businesses, partnerships, trusts or corporate entities which hold or deliver revenue above a suitably deemed amount.
Declare any private or family wealth increases of more than 150% whilst in a parliamentary position or within four years of leaving a position.
Declare any associations and or oaths made to any organisation, society or body, secret or otherwise.

Declare any private associations financial or otherwise made with any national or international corporations, non government organisations, charities, foundations, lobbyist bodies and any other entity deemed to seek influence within the Australian Parliament.

Declare all direct and indirect family associations and agreements financial or otherwise with any national or international corporations, non government organisations, charities, foundations, lobbyist bodies and any other entity deemed to seek influence within the Australian Parliament.
Publicly declare all significant government or private donations for which a member has approved or gifted.
Declared Information by members is to be made in a clear and easily accessible form to the Australian Public.
from 124 citizens (Petition No. EN4045)
Ukraine
The vile military attack on Ukraine by the Russian Federation has acquired the most brazen and cruel form.

The country, which is in the center of Europe, with no anti-missile defence, no protection and equipped shelters, is today subjected to massive ballistic missile attacks and air force bombing. Tanks are shooting at buildings. There are missile attacks on hospitals, schools, kindergartens.

This causes mortal danger to people who only yesterday were living a peaceful life. Today, many people are sitting in underground shelters with the internet offline due to the collapsed power grid infrastructure and avoiding airborne threats.

We all experience pain and, worst of all, a sense of hopelessness because we cannot influence this situation in any way. Many people are now applying for and receiving tourist visas for their parents. We are extremely grateful to the Australian government for the unprecedentedly fast processing times for these visas.

The tourist visa only delays the meeting with the inevitable ruined future. Thus, people, even reunited for a while with their relatives, will remain full of fear of having to return to the land occupied by the enemy.

We therefore ask the House to grant humanitarian visas to Ukrainians that will provide them with hope for the future, give them the opportunity to change their lives and feel safe, work, apply their skills for the benefit of themselves and community.
I urge the government to prioritize family reunification when processing visas from Ukrainian nationals.
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN4046)
Sexual Consent Education

With the dawn of social media platforms like Snapchat and Instagram, young people across Australia have been victim of receiving unsolicited nudes and sexual content from other young people and sometimes even strangers or predators. In 2020, the AIHW published a study saying that over 2 million Australians had been sexually assaulted, and I believe that with mandatory consent education for all kids through all years of high school and even the last year of primary school, these numbers could decrease dramatically and put us on the track on having none.
We therefore ask the House to implement sexual consent education into the curriculum for all Year 6 and High School Students in Australia for every year of school.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN4047)
Natural Disasters

A devastating natural disaster has taken place, lives have been lost and homes destroyed and the government have done nothing to help. Every day civilians are risking their lives to save what they can. pregnant women, the elderly, children, the sick... are facing one of the largest emergencies the area has seen. The government has a responsibility to take action .

We therefore ask the House to send in military services, help create a co-ordinated rescue and recovery effort. Talk to the people who have been working for hours on end and see what is needed. provide water, shelter, relief. The basic human rights people are entitled to.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN4048)
Rural and Regional Radio
PHAZE Country Ballarat broadcasts on 87.6MHz. This frequency is subject to massive interference from another nearby broadcaster making it impossible to listen across much of Ballarat.
We therefore ask the House to make available 97.6MHz and 95.9MHz for allocation to other broadcasters, preferably PHAZE Broadcasting.
from 17 citizens (Petition No. EN4049)
Ukraine

On 24 February, Russia started a war with Ukraine. With each passing day, we see more civilian deaths, despicable war crimes, and a mounting humanitarian crisis. Ukraine does not have the resources to fight back on its own. Only with the help of strong democratic countries can Russian aggression be repelled.
We therefore ask the House to provide increased assistance for the people and government of Ukraine, whether that be:
- Financial assistance
- Military equipment
- Humanitarian aid
- Diplomatic efforts
The people of Ukraine are counting on the free world for assistance. Please help!
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN4051)
Australian Constitution
This petition is to stop Government or agencies trying to erode "we the peoples" right to our constitution, the WHO, is trying to over ride ours, and many other nations peoples rights.
We therefore ask the House to not enter to any contracts with the WHO or other agencies without consent from the people via referendum.
from 546 citizens (Petition No. EN4053)
Bowel Cancer

Bowel cancer is the deadliest cancer for those aged 25 to 44 years old. Currently, the National Bowel Cancer Screening Program is for 50 years and over. This is missing the high risk age group. Bowel cancer diagnosis is rising in people under 50, while declining in those over 50. Those who are diagnosed with young onset bowel cancer are often diagnosed at a later stage, have their symptoms ignored or attributed to other things, with misdiagnosis delaying the treatment in young people.
Early detection is essential in the treatment and improvement of outcomes for patients of this deadly disease.
We therefore ask the House to lower the age of the National Bowel Cancer Screening Program from 50, to 30 years and over. With immediate colonoscopies for those whose results show concerns.
from 2,495 citizens (Petition No. EN4055)
Lismore: Floods

Lismore a City of 40,000 people and district has been devastated by unusually big rains and storms to the degree that Businesses and Homes have been ruined to such an extent that it will take years if ever, be livable in. They need help NOW to clean up and have water and electricity put back in the City. NOW is the time for the ADF to get there and help these people get the City and their lives back to normal.
We therefore ask the House to petition our Government to urgently get hundreds of ADF members to Lismore and district to help the giant cleanup NOW.
from 20 citizens (Petition No. EN4058)
Telecommunications

Lucas, a suburb of the city of Ballarat in western Victoria, is one of the fastest growing suburbs in the region. It is located just 7km from the centre of Ballarat yet has extremely poor telephone and internet reception. Lucas has such poor reception that in some parts of the suburb, residents are unable to make or receive phone calls at all. Some have absolutely no reception inside their homes, while others have one or two "bars".
With the pandemic requiring a lot of people to work from home, this situation is unacceptable.

Lucas is attracting a high level of development, with many new housing estates and homes being built. The area's new primary school is in a telecommunications black spot—many parents are unable to get any reception there at all. There is barely any coverage at the Lucas shopping centre, where the main office of the Ballarat Community Health Centre, and the supermarket, petrol station, and other shops are located.

In this day and age, in a suburb of a major Victorian regional city, we should have exceptional coverage that allows all residents, businesses and organisations to conduct their professional and personal lives without issue.

Despite numerous commitments over several years from Telstra and Optus to instal new telecommunications towers to rectify the issue, this has not happened. We request the Parliament lobby the relevant telecommunications companies to fix the problem immediately.
We therefore ask the House to lobby the relevant telecommunications companies to fix the problem immediately.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN4060)
Nuclear Energy
Climate Change is an increasing threat to the health and security of the Australian people and our nation has a whole. Recent extreme bushfire and flooding events emphasise this increasing threat.

To mitigate climate change requires that we move away from fossil fuels which are contributing to climate change and toward clean energy sources such as solar, wind, and nuclear as identified by peak scientific bodies such as the IPCC.
Australia is the only G20 nation where nuclear power is banned by federal law. This legislation poses a barrier to Australia's transition away from fossil fuels and toward clean, reliable energy.

Australia is already a nuclear nation, operating a research reactor and a range of nuclear technologies, including the production of medical isotopes. Our nation is also an exporter of uranium and has the largest known reserves of uranium. It therefore makes little sense for us to maintain a ban on nuclear energy.

We therefore ask the House to repeal SECT 140A of the ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION ACT 1999, amend the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998, and repeal or amend any other legislation prohibiting the use of nuclear energy.

We ask that the house initiate the International Atomic Energy Agency's (IAEA) milestones approach to start Australia down the path of setting up the regulatory framework needed for nuclear power in Australia.
from 1,273 citizens (Petition No. EN4061)
Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis

A handful of well trained and respected Australian surgeons have been performing Vertebral Body Tethering (VBT) for Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis (AIS) in Private Hospitals for several years. When patients have Private Insurance, the majority of the costs are passed onto the insurer. The biggest cost for the procedure are for the implants, ICU and hospital beds and theatre facility fees. Without an MBS code, a procedure can not be performed utilising private health coverage at a private hospital.

The Medical Services Advice Committee (MSAC) has recommended that VBT be excluded from the current MBS item numbers being used to claim for the procedure. This is despite noting a clinical need for the procedure. It is not a common procedure, and the overall costs to the community are low.

We believe that we should have VBT as an option for treatment of scoliosis in Australia under private health coverage. If not, patients and their families will have to pay between $60,000 and $130,000 out for pocket for the procedure (single curve v 2 curve), even if they have private health coverage.

We therefore ask the House to encourage The Honourable Greg Hunt MP to maintain VBT on the current MBS item numbers being used to claim for the procedure to ensure all parents and carers have VBT as a treatment option for their children suffering from Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis and enjoy the benefits of reduced pain, deformity and an improved quality of life.
from 2,976 citizens (Petition No. EN4062)
Migration

I, like many other Australian settled families, wish to bring my parents to live with us in Australia. But because my parents have three children (one step-son in South Africa, one step-son in the UK and me in Australia) my parents would not pass the Balance of Family test and will be denied an application for a Parent Permanent Visa.

DoHA' states that "a parent meets the balance of family test if: at least half their children and stepchildren are eligible children, or there are more eligible children than children living in any other single country. Immigration does not currently waive this test, even in compelling or exceptional circumstances."

This test is unfair, discriminatory and out of date in modern times. Parents are being discriminated against for having more than 2 children. Parents are being discriminated against for re-marrying and adding step-children to the family unit.

No consideration is made for the Australian adult child having the closest family ties and connection to the parent or for the parents having no or limited relationship with their other overseas children. No consideration is made for the number of grandchildren.

This test is archaic and divisive and should be removed, if not completely overhauled, from the visa application process. Australian adult children and grandchildren should be allowed to live and grow with the people that love them the most, parents and grandparents.
We therefore ask the House to remove the Balance of Family test for Parent visas (permanent).
from 373 citizens (Petition No. EN4064)
Defence
As gender is just a social construct, it's far past time for gender parity in frontline combat roles.
If the beaches of Normandy were stormed with a fighting force that focused on gender parity and inclusivity, there would have been less casualties.
Let us update the military so that our cannon fodder can be comprised of all 76 genders.
Currently, as our military is overwhelmingly comprised of those who identify as "men", conscription should be brought back for those who identify as women/other only until we have gender parity.
We therefore ask the House to bring back conscription with a focus on gender parity, ensuring that all genders are accurately represented in frontline combat roles.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN4069)
Ukraine
National security

We therefore ask the House to ban representatives and persons associated with Ukrainian ultranationalist groups of "National Militia", "Azov movement", "The Right Sector" movement, "Aidar batalion", " Donbass batalion", "Dnepr batailon" from entering Australia as visitors or refugees.
from 33 citizens (Petition No. EN4071)
Fuel

Australians pay $0.44.2 cents per litre of fuel plus 10% GST. The current fuel prices in Australia have risen above $2.20 per litre increasing the cost of living for everyday Australians much more difficult. Countries like France and the Netherlands are reducing taxes and introducing rebates to their citizens to counteract the fuel inflation prices.
More than $49billion will have be collected in fuel taxes from 2020—2024. Australians need to have some of this money placed back in their pockets to help with the cost of living.

Australians have suffered for two years with lockdowns, loss of income and unnecessary mandates, and now we face excessively high fuel prices to be able to get to work, our children to school and to see loved ones that we have been kept from over the past two years.
Australians have suffered enough, suspend fuel taxes.
We therefore ask the House to suspend fuel taxes for 12 months.
from 17 citizens (Petition No. EN4074)
Fuel

I am raising the issue of the continuing rise in petrol costs. It effects all Australians and unless it gets addressed fuel companies will continue to increase prices till low income earning families will be pushed further into poverty.
We therefore ask the House to intervene in the growing prices of petrol or reduce the taxes on petrol for a fair period of time to counteract the increasing fuel prices.
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN4075)
National Security

Switzerland, France, Belgium, Denmark, Austria and the Netherlands have all banned wearing the burqa or any other covering that completely obscures the face in public spaces due to the obvious security concerns and have followed up these laws with on-the-spot fines and even jail time. It is time Australia does the same.

We therefore ask the House to make it illegal to wear a burqa, niqab or any other covering that makes it impossible to identify a person and follow this up with fines and/or jail time for those who break the law.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN4076)
COVID-19: Vaccination
Prevailing medical scientific research has repeatedly shown no significant difference in transmission and infection rates between Covid vaccinated and unvaccinated patients (The Lancet, BMJ).
Moreover, the Australian government is refusing to acknowledge the consistent proof showing that prior infection is equal to, if not greater than, the immunity provided by the current vaccines.
It is therefore unscientific to subject unvaccinated individuals to restrictions with international travel.

We therefore ask the House to review and remove the restrictions currently in place with the Department of Home Affairs for unvaccinated travellers to more scientifically reflect the available research.
from 205 citizens (Petition No. EN4083)
Parliamentarians' Superannuation

Federal Members of Parliament currently have a superannuation contribution of 11.5%. This should be decreased to 10% which will bring it inline with the contribution amount for all Australian workers.

The Australian public wants equity, with the same rights and privileges for all. All Australian workers are hard workers, irrespective of their occupation and there is no good reason that Members of Parliament should be entitled to a higher superannuation rate than everyone else.
We therefore ask the House to change the superannuation percentage of 11.5% to 10% and reflect the 10% that all Australian workers receive.
from 39 citizens (Petition No. EN4084)
Fuel
Current fuel prices on everyday households are unsustainable and government intervention is required.
We therefore ask the House to intervene at any level of the fuel chain and reduce the cost of fuel to households.
from 28 citizens (Petition No. EN4085)
Migration
Skilled immigrants and workers are unable to lodge their application despite meeting all the other eligibility requirements and having the required points for GSM due to expired skill assessment.

Having valid skill assessment is the basic eligibility criteria for skilled migration. And therefore, getting a skill re-assessment for trade occupations is complex and often next to impossible as getting a skill reassessment in trade occupations one is required to do a Job Ready Program or have 3 -5 years of work experience (which is not possible on student visa with limited work rights) unlike for occupations like accounting, nursing, and IT.
As we are aware that there has been a significant shortage in skilled labour across Australia specifically in trade occupations which has negatively impacted production, services, and supply chains.

During the Covid-19 pandemic, Australia's skilled migration for trade occupations was on hold as both the State and Federal government considered only Healthcare and IT sectors. Due to this, the problem of skill shortage in these trade occupations has worsened with many businesses experiencing skill shortages.

Many of our clients who have the required skills in these trade occupations are suffering as they have their skill assessments which was valid for 3 years is now expired as for almost 2 years skilled migration in their occupations was on hold.
We therefore ask the House to amend the regulation for validity period of skills assessment and provide the concession period waiver to skilled immigrants.
from 1,326 citizens (Petition No. EN4086)
Abdominoplasty
Bring back abdominoplasty for mothers after childbirth In latter years on Medicare item no 10177
We therefore ask the House to reconsider this for mothers experiencing health issues from childbearing health
from 31 citizens (Petition No. EN4087)
United Russia

United Russia is a major Russian political party which backs Vladimir Putin and is responsible for legislative approval of numerous laws attacking freedom of speech and personal freedoms, free and fair electoral process, undermining rights of LGBTQ and national minorities and persecution of political opposition. The Party's members are involved in aggressive anti-western rhetoric and responsible for legislative enactment of the military invasions of Ukraine and Georgia, as well as financial support of the Belarus authoritative leader Alexander Lukashenko and multiple far right groups and parties in other countries.
We therefore ask the House to the responsible authorities to

- designate United Russia Party as a terrorist organisation given their history of anti-western rhetoric, approval of the legislation that attacks personal and political rights, their support to the brutal style of governance in the Russian Federation, their continued display of atrocities against sovereign states and their legislative and moral support of the military aggression against Ukraine and recognise that it's activities are incompatible with the shared values of the Australian Community;

- We ask also to ban entry to Australia to the members of the United Russia Party, freeze their assets in international jurisdictions and nominate the Ukrainian humanitarian aid organization as a benefactor of such assets' transfer in consultation with the Ukrainian-Australian community.
from 893 citizens (Petition No. EN4088)
Workplace Relations
Request for house:
As you are aware that a large number of government contracts that are serviced by private companies.

Although there are channels available for employees working for private companies in these government contracts, they are scared to report any matters of significance. This includes corruption, bullying, racism, harassment, intimidation and any other unlawful behavior. This has created imbalance of power. This is because of power of money these organisations have resulting from the amount of money they make from government contracts. This is also resulting in suffering of employees who do not afford to stand up to these organisations because of lack of resources and expertise. These companies are aware that they afford to hire best lawyers to find loopholes in the system and get away with unlawful behavior.
We therefore ask the House to make it mandatory for all government contracts to send out internal surveys, the results of which are only accessible by government.
These surveys should be sent to all employees working for private companies in a government contract.
Employees who are scared to report their employers can then do it through these surveys anonymously.

I strongly believe that this will result into private companies working within the legislation. This will also save those employees who are harassed, bullied and are a victim of racism and discrimination from further suffering. It will save these employees from the mental agony which will result in better performance and less pressure on the government health care system.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN4089)
Personal Information and Privacy

The proposed Digital Identity Legislation is a threat to every Australians privacy and security. We the undersigned vigorously oppose and do not consent to this proposed legislation being passed. We express our overwhelming concern for the following:
• Use and sharing of our personal or biometric information to third parties.
• The lack of clarity about how the private sector will and will not be able to use the scheme.
• The ability to gather detailed profiles of individual Australians.
• Potential misuse, identity fraud and contribution to discriminatory practices, even if indirectly.
• A Western version of China's 'social credit' scheme emerging.

With all the global talks of imminent cyber-attacks, including the QR Code data breaches in Victoria and NSW, it is evident that Australians personal information will not be kept safe within a digital identity framework.

We therefore ask the House to stay with the status quo MyGov as our one and only digital identity in Australia. We as Australians, have the right to private life, home and correspondence as a protection, the right to trade freely within the Commonwealth, the right to be free from discrimination and the compliance and compatibility of all acts, bills and legislations with our Human Rights.

We trust that you will do the right thing by all Australian's including for our children and all future generations by not passing the Digital Identity Legislation, so we can continue to live in a country where our privacy and freedoms are protected and celebrated.
from 46,232 citizens (Petition No. EN4090)
Migration

Due to persecution by Chinese government against Chinese family (house) churches, and forced closure of Christian educational organizations, members of Shenzhen Holy Reformed Church (SHRC), which includes 29 adults (2 of whom are pregnant) and 31 children, were forced into exile on Jeju Island, Korea at the end of 2019.
These 31 children studied in the school established by SHRC, but the school was forced to close by the government.
These members of SHRC gave up their normal life in China and are working casually in farms on Jeju Island. They are called "The New Mayflower" internationally.

However, due to the fact that the Korean government doesn't have many previous precedents to provide asylum to non-Korean refugees, Kwangju Superior Court of Korea dismissed SHRC members' final appeal for asylum. Now members of SHRC are faced with forced deportation back to China.

If members of SHRC are deported back to China, they will face severe persecution by the Chinese government. Some members who stayed in China and didn't go to Jeju Island were interrogated, monitored, even put under home arrest.
The relatives of members who went to Jeju Island have also experienced threats, interrogation and harassments.
Australia is a democratic country with a great history of supporting persecuted people.
Therefore, we request that the Australian government (or Parliament) provide humanitarian support to these 60 members of SHRC who are now exile in Jeju Island, Korea.
We therefore ask the House to issue contingent visas to them so they can find shelter in Australia.
from 40 citizens (Petition No. EN4091)
Public Sector Governance

Should Australian public officials, such as politicians and bureaucrats be subject to consequences, under Commonwealth and State laws, such as investigation and prosecution, if they are found to be breaking the law, in the same way as any other Australian citizen would be? If so, please sign the petition.

Much has been said about the need for a Federal Independent Anti-Corruption Commission; the Morrison government even has some draft legislation that's never been debated. All this fails to recognize that the instruments of integrity and accountability already exist within the current framework.

These instruments begin with the PUBLIC SERVICE ACT 1999, Section 13; The APS Code of Conduct. Then there is the Office of Prime Minister & Cabinet's (the Australian government's) Statement of Ministerial Standards. Both of these instruments have an enormous amount to say about principles, values, integrity, fairness, accountability, the public interest etc. They should, in fact have all of this well-and-truly covered within the existing framework. Although most of us understand that none of these instruments are actually applied in real day-to-day practice.

Most frighteningly of all, these 'special' (as opposed to 'ordinary') Australians are allowed to carry out their business, above and beyond any scrutiny from our LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES, so these special Australians are protected within a lawless bubble, where any & all serious allegations of criminal misconduct are ignored, brushed aside and treated with contempt.
We therefore ask the House to insist that existing Codes, Standards and Laws are equally enforced—even against your special Australians.
from 85 citizens (Petition No. EN4095)
Gold Holdings

Recent international events such as the freezing of Russia's foreign held currency and gold reserves, and the Bank of England refusing to return Venezuela's gold reserve, highlight the counter party risk of continuing to physically store Australia's 80 tonnes of gold at the Bank of England in London. Despite our ties to the UK via Her Majesty, Queen Elizabeth II and her heirs as set out in the Constitution of Australia, and despite any legal agreement entered with the Bank of England, there may come a day in the future whereby the UK Government does not recognise an Australian Government and thereby does not respect the sovereignty of Australia's gold held at the Bank of England, with resultant risk of our gold being effectively seized by the UK. The Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia is on the public record as stating that there is no requirement for Australia's gold to be physically moved in order for it to be leased, audited, or otherwise dealt with. Therefore we put forth that there is no benefit to Australia in continuing to store its gold reserves at the Bank of England and that to continue to do so risks Australia's sovereignty and independence. The UK has demonstrated in the past to have acted contrary to Australia's interest/s and there is a risk of it doing so again in the future.
We therefore ask the House to BRING HOME OUR GOLD!
from 66 citizens (Petition No. EN4096)
Social Media

It has been well documented that Mark Zuckerberg (Meta/Facebook/Instagram/WhatsAp) meddled in the 2020 USA Presidential Election and now many media outlets are reporting that META are now planning to "help train Australian political candidates on aspects of cyber security and coach influencers to stop the spread of misinformation in a bid to boost the integrity of an upcoming election," according to a Reuters report.
We therefore ask the House to BAN the company META (Mark Zuckerberg/Facebook/Instagram/WhatsAp) from Australia PERMANENTLY and list them as a danger to Australia's integrity.
WE do not want their meddling in our elections with their censorship and misinformation.
from 218 citizens (Petition No. EN4097)
Parliamentary Standards
Globally, democratic norms are suffering duress through corporate manipulation and an erosion of government accountability.
Australia must strengthen its democratic institutions if it is to remain a healthy, liberal democracy.
We therefore ask the House to legislate to implement:

1. The Uluru Statement from the Heart. As a former colonial country, Australia will only be entitled to consider itself a healthy democracy after it's fully made its peace with its First Nations' People.
2. A national Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) with the appropriate legal authority to prosecute all forms of political corruption.
3. A redrafting of Australia's media ownership laws to end monopoly control across all media platforms. Diversity of informed opinion is the lifeblood of any healthy democracy.
4. A system to ensure that Parliamentary elections become fully government funded.

5. The removal of all corporate money and influence from elections. Individual donations to political parties should not exceed $1000 with requirements that the public donations' record is made fully transparent & up-dated monthly.

6. A ban on all corporate lobbying and the expulsion of the 800+ corporate lobbyists currently manipulating the political process in Canberra for the sole purpose of benefiting corporations' profitability.
7. The creation of an independent Parliamentary Commission to ensure the on-going protection of, and funding for, the 11 existing, key democratic accountability bodies (the AEC, ABC, ANAO, etc.)
8. A Parliamentary Accountability Body with sufficient legal powers to enforce respectful & decent behaviour from all Parliamentary Members and public servants.
from 319 citizens (Petition No. EN4099)
Standards Australia

Currently Australian Standards are restricted to professionals, tradesmen and organisations through a private entity. These standards are becoming increasingly expensive and the restrictions on accessibility are increasing. These standards are essential to ensure the safety and operability of our infrastructure and our services to the public. For a single task or service, a number of these standards may be required. These standards are also constantly being revised so new versions are required. Some standards are mandated by legislation. Many of the people that require these standards are in small organisations or even sole traders that cannot support these overheads. This in essence will force small organisations and sole traders out of business or necessitate services being performed without having access to these standards. The existing model is unsustainable and will potentially lead to incidents, inoperability and disruption to operational infrastructure. An example: A small electrical engineering company with 10 people that perform electrical design may need access to 100s of standards on a single project. The cost of these is greater then the profit margin on this project.

We therefore ask the House to provide stronger oversight and/or mandates to the organisations controlling access to Australian Standards to make these readily available for free or at a reasonable cost to all people in Australia who require these standards to perform their duties.
from 22,526 citizens (Petition No. EN4101)
Illicit Drugs: Cannabis
Cannabis is used legally and illegally by approximately 60% of the population. There is a significant overlap between recreational and medicinal use.

Legalisation would allow for a regulated market that increases safety to consumers, improved safeguarding of minors, reduces criminality, and can provide significant tax income to state and federal governments.

Legalisation would allow for the development of a cannabis industry which can benefit the economy. Industries that would benefit include natural supplement companies, tourism, and the hospitality industry.
Positive benefits would include reduced costs related to policing, court costs, and incarceration costs.
We therefore ask the House to legalise cannabis.
from 1,477 citizens (Petition No. EN4102)
Commonwealth Coat of Arms

Kangaroos are protected but under a government management plan they can be culled if populations are considered in plague proportions. Therefore being considered a pest to the farmer and there livelihood. I question how the government calculates the kangaroo populations and to the accuracy of the prediction. I question how the Kangaroo is also considered a viable sustainable resource. How does conservation and commercial culling of a species go together when considered a sustainable resource. I question the price the government is putting on the kangaroo's heads and are they over commercialising on our national icon. A icon that appears on Australian Coat of Arms. Are professional shooters managing to get their quota's or are Kangaroos becoming hard to find. This happened to our crocodiles before they became protected and no longer able to be shot. It is a national tragedy waiting to happen like our Koala's that are now on the endangered list.

We therefore ask the House to take the Kangaroo off our Coat of Arms as it is no longer being loved but treated as a commercial asset to the government. Under the pretence of being in plague proportions. Considered a pest! Should there be a pest on the Australian Coat of Arms.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN3952)
First Aid Training
Following the death of five-year-old Lucas Latouche Mazzei, it has become evidently eye opening how important it is for students within a teachers care to be safe and protected.

We therefore ask the House to mandate first aid training so that teachers can fulfil their duty of care by recognising and responding effectively to students in need of first aid treatment. Students are with their teacher for approximately 7 hours a day, it is so imperative that they understand the basic and necessary skills that could save a child's life, or even a colleague. Parents drop their loved ones at school trusting that they will be looked after, this is the bare minimum that students deserve.
It is mandatory in every state except for SA and WA. I kindly urge you to please look into this.
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN3955)
Pensions and Benefits
The current Jobseeker amount is $629.50 for a Single person and Rent assistance $142.80.

We therefore ask the House to Annually Economically evaluate (without considering sharehouse bulking 2-6 single people per rooms which lessens averages) the Centrelink Governance of respectful and responsible Cost of Living all Centrelink payments. It is estimated the average Quality of Life amount should be an extra $200+ fortnight 2022. Legislation is requested to ensure homelessness and neglect is not possible with annual economic management.
from 20 citizens (Petition No. EN3957)
Migration
Why rules in Australia to call to your parents permanently is so harsh as compared to Canada and US?
Subclass 143, The fee is AUD47,825 for 1 parent and time frame is 2-5 years with no pension given for first 10 years.
Subclass 103 processing time is 30 -50 years which is not realistic.

How is it expected from the parents who are already at the retirement age to wait for that long or pay $96,000 come to australia then find a job, work for 10 years, pay taxes and healthcare and afford everything?
Also, for a tourist visa they can only stay for 3 months max, and get 1 year visa for which they have 100s of documents to collect submit and apply.
This issue has to be addressed.

from 825 citizens (Petition No. EN4023)
Chronic Pain

Data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics indicated that 1 in 5 Australians (19% or 1.6 million) aged 45 years and over experience chronic pain; a common, complex condition characterised by persistent pain experienced most days of the week (Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, May 2020, 'Chronic Pain in Australia'). The cost to the Australian economy through quality of life and productivity loss is estimated to be $139 billion. The long term cost of chronic pain is significantly increased as additional long-term health conditions are experienced concurrently. The Commonwealth government recently made a decision to make fundamental changes to the Medicare Benefits Scheme ("MBS") that will come into effect on 1 March 2022, critically impacting every chronic pain sufferer in Australia. The Federal Government sought limited or no feedback and consultation on the proposed changes. Feedback by the Faculty of Pain Medicine, Australian and New Zealand College of Anaethetists was completely ignored. These proposed changes include a change to the item numbers allowing patients to have substantial costs covered under the MBS and private health insurers for a total of 3 times from any region within a 12 month period. Current practice allows for up to 8 joints per treatment session. Treatment costs will blow out to a point where chronic pain sufferers can no longer afford treatment, increasing short and long-term health crises as well as the loss to Australia's economy.
We therefore ask the House to comprehensively risk assess these standards and consequences more prior to implementation.

We therefore ask the House to remove the maximum attempts for LANTITE
