PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Foreign Investment
Dear Chair,

I refer to your email of 13 May 2021 regarding petition number EN2468 to investigate the claims of Keswick Island residents and cancel the lease of the Chinese company China Bloom. I regret the delay in responding.

The Government recognises the important role foreign investment plays in supporting our economic wellbeing. Australia, as a very large country with a relatively small population, has always relied on foreign investment to create jobs, provide revenues, and support export opportunities for Australian businesses. As Australia moves towards economic recovery from the COVID-19 crisis, our openness to international trade and investment remains vital. This is especially the case in regions such as North Queensland, which were disproportionately impacted by the closure of Australia's international borders.

The Government has a rigorous regime in place to ensure all foreign investment is in the national interest. This includes agricultural, commercial and residential property. The Government has introduced registers of foreign ownership of residential and agricultural land to provide greater transparency to foreign ownership of these assets.

It is important to note that just because Australia accepts foreign investment, it doesn't mean we lose the ability to set the rules with which all companies, domestic and foreign-owned, must comply. All companies are subject to Australian legislation and regulations, be it our taxation laws, our environmental and safety standards, and our labour market requirements.

I am aware that the Queensland Government has recently established a parliamentary inquiry to examine island resort management across Queensland, including Keswick Island. The Queensland Government's Transport and Resources Committee is now inviting submissions addressing any aspect of the inquiry from all interested parties. I commend that process to all concerned residents of Keswick Island.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment, Mr Tehan
Parents and Carers
Dear Chair,

Thank you for your email of 9 August 2021 to the Hon Greg Hunt MP, Minister for Health and Aged Care concerning petition number EN2738 'protection of parents during pregnancy, childbirth and infancy of children'. As the issues raised fall within my portfolio responsibilities as the Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, your email was referred to me for reply. I apologise for the delayed response.

The Australian Government is committed to eliminating discrimination against parents in their work life and in the arrangements they make for accommodation. The federal Sex Discrimination Act 1984 makes it unlawful to discriminate on the basis of sex, marital or relationship status, pregnancy or potential pregnancy, breastfeeding and family responsibilities in ce1iain areas of public life, including employment and accommodation.

If anyone believes they have been unlawfully discriminated against, they can contact the Australian Human Rights Commission. The Commission has the power to investigate and attempt to conciliate complaints of discrimination. If a conciliation is unsuccessful or a complaint is terminated, in ce1iain circumstances a complainant may commence legal proceedings regarding the complaint in the Federal Court of Australia or the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia. Information on the Commission's complaint handling process is available online at: www.humamights.gov.au/complaints-information.

Additionally, the Fair Work Act 2009 (Fair Work Act) provides a range of minimum entitlements and protections for employees who are pregnant or are parents of children. Many employers provide additional entitlements above the minimum standards set out in the Fair Work Act, through enterprise agreements or individual contracts.

Under the National Employment Standards (NES) in the Fair Work Act, parental leave and related entitlements provide minimum leave entitlements for all employees. The core component of parental leave is the right to up to 52 weeks of unpaid parental leave for eligible employees, with a right to request an additional 12 months of unpaid parental leave with a limit of 24 months of leave per employed couple.

Employees who have taken unpaid parental leave are entitled to return to their job following their leave or, if their position no longer exists, an available position they are qualified for and suited nearest in status and pay to their pre-parental leave position.

You may be aware that in 2020, the Government passed the Fair Work Amendment (Improving Unpaid Parental Leave for Parents of Stillborn Babies and Other Measures) Act. This legislation provides improved support to families experiencing the trauma of stillbirth, premature birth and the death of an infant in the first 24 months of life. For parents of premature babies, or newborns that experience birth-related complications that result in immediate hospitalisation following birth, these measures provide families a choice if they wish to put their unpaid parental leave on hold, return to work by agreement with their employer while their baby remains in hospital, and resume unpaid parental leave on a later date. The legislation also allows employee parents to take up to 30 days of their existing unpaid parental leave entitlement on a flexible (including day-at-a-time) basis to complement the changes to the Government's 18-week Paid Parental Leave Scheme to give parents greater flexibility around how they access their Parental Leave Payment.

span.span: Transfer to a safejob and no safejob leave

p.span: The NES includes entitlements that promote the safety of pregnant employees. All pregnant employees who are unable to safely perform their job are entitled to move to a safe job if one is available at the same the same pay rate, hours of work and with entitlements they receive in their normal job. The employee and the employer can agree on different working hours however the employee will stay in the safe job position until it is safe for them to go back to their normal job, or until they give birth. The employee will need to give the employer evidence that the employee can work but cannot do their normal job (including why the normal job is not safe), and how long the employee should not work in the normal job. The employer can ask for a medical certificate from the employee as evidence.

A pregnant employee who is entitled to move to a safe job but there is no safe job available, will be entitled to no safe job leave. If the employee is entitled to unpaid parental leave, their no safe job leave will be paid at their base rate of pay for ordinary hours of work. Employees who are not entitled to unpaid parental leave can take unpaid no safe job leave.

Under the NES, eligible employees also have the right to request flexible working arrangements in a range of circumstances. This includes employees who are parents or have responsibility for the care of a child who is school-aged or younger. New working arrangements can include changes to hours, patterns and locations of work. Employees must be a permanent employee with at least 12 months' continuous service, or a long-term casual employee with a reasonable expectation of continuing employment with their employer on a regular and systematic basis.
The Fair Work Act also protects employees and prospective employees in the national industrial relations system from discrimination at work.

Under the general protections provisions, employers must not take adverse action against employees or prospective employees because of a protected attribute (including, for example, dismissing or discriminating against an employee because of their pregnancy or family or carer responsibilities). This is the case unless the adverse action falls within a relevant exception, including if the action is taken because of the inherent requirements of the particular position concerned. These provisions provide an appropriate balance between workplace protections and certainty for employers.

Further information about entitlements and protections in the Fair Work Act, including advice tailored to specific· circumstances, can be found through the Fair Work Ombudsman at www.fairwork.gov.au or via phone on 13 13 94.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Michaelia Cash
Beauty Industry
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 9 August 2021 to my predecessor concerning Petition EN2758, requesting financial support for the beauty industry.

The COVID-19 pandemic, bushfires, and floods have had a significant impact on small businesses across the country. As such, a priority for the new Government is to address the needs of small businesses in times of crisis, giving the confidence and certainty to grow and plan for the future. The Government will work closely with states, territories, industry groups and communities to end the uncertainty that surrounds the support small businesses are able to access in a crisis.

I would also encourage small owners who need support to access the Australian Government's primary assistance channel, available at www.business.gov.au. This service is also available by phone on: 13 28 46, operating seven days per week from 8:00 am to 8:00 pm across Australia, or through an online enquiry form or web chat. This simple and streamlined service includes expert operators who are experienced at running small businesses and able to help with topics such as obtaining finance, managing cash flow, taxation, small business counselling and information technology.
I trust this information will be of assistance to those who submitted the petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Small Business, MsCollins
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October 2021, enclosing Petition EN2957 with 23 signatures, seeking to allow international travel for vaccinated Australian citizens and permanent residents.

Australia's international border settings have played a critical role in protecting the health of Australians. The Australian Government continues to take proactive steps to ensure the safe reopening of the border at a scale supported by health advice, and in a manner consistent with the National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response (National Plan).

As of 21 February 2022, all fully vaccinated visa holders, including those with a visitor visa, will be able to enter Australia without a travel exemption. This further re-opening of our international border will ensure we protect the health of Australians, while we continue to secure our economic recovery.

The Australian Border Force Commissioner's travel exemption system will remain in place for unvaccinated travellers. Visa holders who are not fully vaccinated will still require a valid travel exemption to enter Australia, and will be subject to state and territory quarantine requirements.
The most up-to-date announcements and information on who can travel to Australia, and the requirements that apply can be found at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2957 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
National Day of Prayer
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 18 October 2021 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, relating to a petition about a National Day of Prayer in Parliament (Petition no. EN3152). The Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf. I sincerely apologise for the delay in responding.

As you would be aware, Order 38 of the Standing Orders of the House of Representatives provides that at the beginning of each sitting, the Speaker shall make an acknowledgment of country and then read the prayer set out in the order (known as the 'Lord's prayer'). Similar provision is made by Order 50 of the Standing Orders of the Senate. This has been the practice of the Parliament over a number of years.

It is important that everyone has an opportunity to have their say about the issues that matter to them. The constituents' views on this particular issue have been carefully noted and will be taken into account.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton
NT Working Women's Centre
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October to Senator the Hon Jane Hume regarding a petition that requests ongoing funding for Northern Territory Working Women's Centre (NTWWC). As this issue falls within my portfolio 2021 responsibilities as the Attorney- General and Minister for Industrial Relations, your correspondence was referred to me for reply.

As part of the Australian Government's response to recommendation 49 of the Respect@Work: Sexual Harassment National Inquiry Report (the Respect@Work Report), the Government is providing a further $175,000 in 2021-22 to support the continued operation of the NTWWC, bringing the total commitment to the NTWWC in 2021-22 to $275,000. The Attorney-General's Department advised the NTWWC on 14 February 2022 that it will receive an additional $175,000 from the Government in 2021-22 bringing the total amount of funding in 2021-22 to $550,000.

As announced in the 2022-23 Budget, the Government is also providing a further $1.8 million over three years from 2022-23 to fund the delivery of critical information, advice and assistance to women who experience workplace sexual harassment, and other workplace issues. This funding will be provided through a grant opportunity made available to NTWWC and Working Women Queensland. NTWWC has been invited to apply for a grant of up to $350,000 per year from 1 July 2022 to 31December 2024. This equates to 50 per cent of the identified annual funding need of $700,000 for NTWWC, noting that that recommendation 49 of the Respect@Work Report was directed to all governments (Commonwealth and states and territories) and funding these services is a shared responsibility.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Michaelia Cash(Petition No. EN3178)
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence concerning petition number EN3239 requesting the House to enact a bill to adopt and implement the use of rapid antigen testing across Australia. I regret the delay in responding.

Supply of rapid antigen test (RAT) kits is an urgent and immediate focus of National Cabinet. The Australian Government has provided authority, and approved additional funding, to ensure consistent supply of RAT kits to high-need areas to manage health impacts, protect vulnerable Australians and minimise disruption to daily life.

To date the Department has procured over 95 million RATs for use in areas of Commonwealth responsibility, currently including aged care, National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS), Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations (ACCHOs), and GP-led Respiratory Clinics (GRPCs).

Over 40 million have been supplied to residential aged care facilities, ACCHOs, Supported Independent Living (SIL) services and GRPCs, including 11 million to states and territories. RATs have also been procured for SIL residents and workers through the NDIS.

The direct supply of test kits to these settings is in addition to previously announced measures including free RATs as part of the COVID-19 Rapid Test Concessional Access (CRTCA) Program. As part of winter preparedness, the Commonwealth extended the CRTCA Program until 31 July 2022, in partnership with the states.

The Government has worked closely in partnership with the pharmacy sector, including the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and pharmacy groups, to design, agree and implement the CRTCA Program rules and remuneration structure.

Under the CRTCA Program rules, pharmacies participating in the CRTCA Program are currently reimbursed $10 plus GST per test (based on the average wholesale price of RATs) supplied, and a handling and administration fee of$4.30 per supply transaction processed under this scheme.

The renumeration structure of the CRTCA Program has been informed by industry information and discussed and agreed with key pharmacy stakeholders as an appropriate level of reimbursement for this time-limited program.
As of 18 March 2022, participating pharmacies have provided more than 23 million RAT kits to over 3.8 million eligible Concession Card holders since the CRTCA Program commenced on 24 January 2022.

In addition to this, the first payment under the CRTCA Program was made by the Pharmacy Programs Administrator and was processed on Tuesday 15 February 2022—nearly two weeks earlier than initially indicated in the CRTCA Program rules.

Please note that polymerase chain reaction and rapid antigen testing for COVID-19 remains free for people who are suspected to have COVID-19 or who are close contacts, through Government-run testing clinics.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt

subdebateinfo.title: Compensation for Detriment Caused by Defective Administration Scheme

p.span: Compensation for Detriment Caused by Defective Administration Scheme
Dear Mr O'Dowd

I am writing in response to your letter of 22 November 2021 to the Attorney-General, Senator the Hon Michaelia Cash, seeking a response to petition number EN3251. Your letter was referred to me as I have policy responsibility for the Scheme for Compensation for Detriment caused by Defective Administration (CDDA Scheme).

The CDDA Scheme has operated since 1997 and was established to deliver an easily accessible administrative scheme to enable complaints about defective administration by the Commonwealth to be considered and resolved. The CDDA Scheme operates on the basis of authority provided to individual portfolio ministers under the executive power of sections 61 and 64 of the Constitution and senior officials authorised by a minister.

A minister has a very broad discretion to authorise payments in compensation for defective administration. It would be very difficult to legislate a CDDA Scheme without potentially limiting the broad discretion currently available to ministers.

The Department of Finance issues policy guidance for agencies and individuals in Resource Management Guide 409: Scheme for Compensation caused by Defective Administration (RMG 409), which is published on the Department of Finance website, www.finance.gov.au.

RMG 409 sets out a range of matters to be considered by agencies in deciding a CDDA Scheme claim. This includes requirements to ensure the claimant is provided with procedural fairness (paragraph 39) and to provide an adequate explanation of the reasons for a decision (paragraph 78).

CDDA decisions made by delegated senior officials are open to review by the Commonwealth Ombudsman. As the petition has identified, CDDA Scheme decisions are not made under an enactment or law, so decisions are not amenable to judicial review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. However, CDDA Scheme decisions may be subject to judicial review under section 75 of the Constitution or section 39B(l) of the Judiciary Act 1903 (RMG 409, paragraph 92).
Given the above I am not satisfied that there is a need to legislate the CDDA Scheme or to provide access to a formal external merits review process as outlined in the petition.
I have copied this letter to the Attorney-General.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Finance, Mr Birmingham
Veterans
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning Petition No EN3361 seeking amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to require the Repatriation Medical Authority to insert a factor in Statements of Principles providing a link to service for the worsening of a medical condition caused by "a failure to be provided appropriate clinical management" for the medical condition (for said injury or disease) where the evidence indicates a factor for "an inability to obtain appropriate clinical management".

The Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 establishes the Repatriation Medical Authority whose function is to determine Statements of Principles which are legislative instruments setting out the factors which connect particular medical conditions, be they injuries or diseases, with the circumstances of military service. The Statements of Principles are the point of reference in assessing whether any claimed hypothesis connecting a medical condition to service is reasonable or whether a decision-maker can be reasonably satisfied about the connection between a medical condition and service (see sections 120A and 120B of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and section 338 and section 339 of the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004).

Since its inception, the Repatriation Medical Authority has generally included a factor in its Statements of Principles for a service related inability to obtain medical treatment for the relevant condition where that inability has caused or contributed to the worsening of the disease or injury. That factor currently refers to "an inability to obtain appropriate clinical management".

The matter of such an inability related to service has been the subject of judicial consideration, most notably by the Full Court of the Federal Court in Repatriation Commission v Money (2009) 173 FCR 410 where Justices Finn and Edmonds held that:

the expression "appropriate clinical management" goes beyond positive treatment of an injury or disease and includes advice that could be given to a patient such as to desist from certain activities or to take other steps as measures to preclude aggravation or exacerbation of an injury or disease (at [43]); and the inability to obtain appropriate clinical management must occasion the material contribution to, or aggravation of the injury or disease (at [42] and [59]).

The link to service here is provided by the reference to a service related 'inability'. It is interpreted generously. For example, section 1968(14)(b) provides that a factor for a disease is relevantly 'related to service' if it 'was attributable to, that service'. In Repatriation Commission v Money, the Court found that the test of attribution was satisfied when there was a 'systems failure of the Navy's medical management structure' which resulted in Mr Money's lung disease (idiopathic fibrosing alveolitis) not being diagnosed.

Here however, the petitioner seeks an amendment, presumably to section 1968(14) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, to have any 'failure to be provided appropriate clinical management' specified as being 'related to service' thereby eliminating the requirement to show such an inability.

Given the approach to assessment of inability outlined in Money v Repatriation Commission such a change would be of marginal benefit to claimants, if any. It would, however, have at least three effects thereby changing the nature of the compensation system:

Such an amendment is predicated on a change in the current understanding as to how factors are 'related to service' as outlined in Repatriation Commission v Money and would effectively abolish the requirement for a direct or contributory relationship.

The proposed amendment would introduce a specific link to service for a 'failure to be provided appropriate clinical management' in section 1968(14) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 when the other provisions are general in nature.

This change would lead to a change in focus in the presentation and assessment of a compensation claim from the circumstances of the claimant to an examination of alleged deficiencies in any clinical management by Defence whether that was occasioned by any inability of the claimant or not.
This change would considerably enlarge the timeframes needed to assess claims.

The Productivity Commission in its review of veterans' compensation, A Better Way to Support Veterans endorsed the Statement of Principles system as 'robust and effective' and noted the widespread support for it. It said the system:
promotes consistency, predictability and transparency and draws a clear line between accepted and non-accepted conditions, based on sound medical scientific evidence'. [p.349]
In my view the petitioner's proposed change would not enhance this outcome. Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Gee
Veterans
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 December 2021 regarding Petition number EN3362, which requests the House to initiate processes to require the Secretary of the Department of Veterans' Affairs to conform with section 137 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and cease the practice of including 'other material' and 'other information' in reports provided to the Veterans' Review Board under that provision. The Petition suggests that this will 'return natural justice to the decision review processes'.
This Petition raises very similar issues to Petition EN3399 and EN3037, about which I have written to you separately.

As previously discussed, section 137 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 applies when a veteran seeks review by the Veterans' Review Board of a decision of the Repatriation Commission in respect of a claim for a pension or other benefit under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. Under section 137, the Secretary must arrange for a report to be prepared which refers to the 'evidence' that is under the control of the Department of Veterans' Affairs that is relevant to the Veterans' Review Board's review of the claim.

The Secretary adopts a broad interpretation of 'evidence' when preparing a report under section 137 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. This helps ensure that all relevant material is provided for the Veterans' Review Board's consideration when it is undertaking a review.

As Petition EN3362 notes, the Repatriation Commission, rather than the Secretary, also has the power under section 138 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to make available to the Veterans' Review Board other material the Repatriation Commission considers may be of assistance to the Veterans' Review Board in relation to its review.

The reference to 'other material' in section 138 extends beyond 'evidence' relating to a particular claim. This would include, amongst other things, policy documents and guidance materials of general relevance, rather than material that is relevant only to a specific claim. This is reinforced by the Explanatory Memorandum to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill 1985, which outlined that the provision would allow the Repatriation Commission to make available to the Veterans' Review Board 'material which may aid in encouraging consistency in decision making but will not be able to direct the Veterans Review Board in the consideration of a particular review'. It therefore goes beyond material that is only relevant to the particular claim under review.

Contrary to the Petition's assertion, I consider that a failure to provide all material that is relevant to a review under section 137 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 may undermine natural justice, because a veteran has the opportunity to comment on that material before it is provided to the Veterans' Review Board. It would not be in the interests of veterans for such material to be withheld until some later point in time. Nor would it assist the Veterans' Review Board to achieve its statutory objective of providing a mechanism of review that is 'fair, just, economical, informal and quick'.
Accordingly, there are no plans to require the Secretary to adopt a narrower approach to preparing a report under section 137 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.
Thank you for bringing the concerns set out in Petition number EN3362 to my attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Gee
Veterans
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021 regarding Petition number EN3367, which requests the House to initiate processes to require the Secretary of the Department of Veterans' Affairs (OVA) to comply with what is stated to be the statutory intent of section 137 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, by ceasing the practice of compiling 'evidence reports', which are provided to the Veterans' Review Board for the purposes of a review, by including evidence from multiple matters.

Section 137 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 applies when a veteran seeks review by the Veterans' Review Board of a decision of the Repatriation Commission or Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission in respect of a claim for a pension or other benefit. Under section 137, the Secretary must arrange for a report to be prepared which refers to the 'evidence' that is under the control of OVA that is 'relevant' to the Veterans' Review Board's review of the claim (section 137 report). Section 137 is a procedural provision intended to ensure OVA provides all relevant documents for a veteran appeal to the Veterans' Review Board.

The Petition challenges the practice of preparing section 137 reports where there are multiple applications for review in respect of a single decision. The current practice is, where multiple applications for review relating to a single decision are lodged within days of one another, the documents relevant to all applications for review are combined into one section 137 report. If, however, a subsequent application for review is received after a section 137 report has been already been issued for the previous application(s) for review, then a separate section 137 report is prepared.

The purpose of this practice is for the Secretary to provide all relevant information to the Veterans' Review Board and to do so in the most practical and efficient way. This practice is also important to provide full context to the decision under review in order to ensure the Veterans' Review Board has a complete picture of the issue(s) before it.

The Petition states where a veteran withdraws an application for review, irrelevant information will be before the Veterans' Review Board. I agree this may occur in some cases. However, this does not override the need to ensure all relevant documents are relevant to a review are before the Veterans' Review Board in the first instance. Further, what is relevant to the review may change as the matter progresses. A failure to provide relevant documents at the earliest opportunity would affect the ability of the Veterans' Review Board to properly conduct its review, and to achieve its statutory objective of providing a mechanism of review that is 'fair, just, economical, informal and quick'.

DVA has drafted guidelines entitled 'Compilation of Section 137 reports', which set out the procedures in relation to the documents a decision-maker must lodge with the Veterans' Review Board under this section. Following the Federal Court decision of Shafran v Repatriation Commission [2019] FCA 1833 (Shafran), operational changes to the process pursuant to section 137 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 were made in order to address the issues identified in that judgment. The operational changes are intended to establish a clear process for the provision of material relevant to a review. One of the actions taken include a comprehensive review of, and update to, the policy guidelines. The revised guidelines, entitled 'Compliance with section 137 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, are currently being finalised and are expected to be published shortly. They will provide more detailed guidance, including on what documents ought to be included in a section 137 report.

The Shafran decision also identified practice changes were required in order to allow the opportunity for veterans to make comments before the section 137 report is provided to the Veterans' Review Board. Pursuant to section 137(3) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, a veteran has 28 days to respond to or make comments on the section 137 report, or to request an extension of time within which to do so. This gives a veteran the opportunity to ask that any document be removed from a section 137 report if they do not consider it is not relevant to the review.

Overall, the current practice by DVA is to include documents in a section 137 report that are considered to be relevant to the Veterans' Review Board's review. Where appropriate, DVA will try to narrow the scope of the material that is included in the section 137 report if the veteran identifies that they only take issue with certain aspects of a decision (where more than one issue is covered in the same decision). In all cases, a forensic decision is made as to what documents are relevant for the purposes of the review. Accordingly, there are no plans to require the Secretary to initiate a different process.
Thank you for bringing the concerns set out in Petition number EN3399 to my attention.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Gee
Electric Vehicles
Dear Secretary

In the previous Parliament, the then Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, Mr Ken O'Dowd MP, wrote to the then Treasurer concerning Petition EN3386 on electric cars. That petition has been referred to me for response.

The Government has committed to introducing an Electric Car Discount (the Discount) to make electric vehicles cheaper so that more families who want them can afford them, and to reduce emissions. The Discount will remove import tariffs and the fringe benefits tax from eligible electric vehicles below the luxury car tax (LCT) threshold for fuel efficient vehicles. To support the Discount, the Government has also committed to work with industry, unions, states and consumers to develop Australia's first National Electric Vehicle Strategy, which will further consider measures to increase electric vehicles take up.

In relation to the LCT specifically, fuel-efficient vehicles, including electric vehicles, already receive beneficial treatment to encourage take-up. The LCT is applied at a rate of 33 per cent of the OST-inclusive price of vehicles which exceed the LCT threshold. The 2022-23 threshold is $71,849 for ordinary vehicles and $84,916 for fuel-efficient vehicles.

The Government has no plans to change how the LCT applies to electric vehicles. The Government uses the revenue from the LCT to fund essential services that all Australians benefit from such as health, education and defence. The cost of electric vehicle technology is rapidly declining, with many vehicles coming on to the Australian market already priced below the fuel efficient LCT threshold. These vehicles will not attract any LCT.

In addition, a number of state and territories provide incentives for the uptake of electric vehicles, such as reduced stamp duty and vehicle registration fees. Another factor that encourages take-up is that drivers of electric vehicles do not pay fuel excise for the ongoing operation of their vehicles.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
Veterans
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 22 November 2021 regarding Petition number EN3399, which requests the House to initiate processes to require the Secretary of the Department of Veterans' Affairs (OVA) to comply with what is stated to be the statutory intent of section 137 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, by only including 'evidence' rather than 'other material' in reports provided to the Veterans' Review Board for the purposes of a review.

Section 137 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 applies when a veteran seeks review by the Veterans' Review Board of a decision of the Repatriation Commission in respect of a claim for a pension or other benefit under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. Under section 137, the Secretary must arrange for a report to be prepared which refers to the 'evidence' that is under the control of OVA that is relevant to the Veterans' Review Board's review of the claim. In circumstances where the term 'evidence' is not defined in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, the Secretary adopts the ordinary meaning of 'evidence' for the purposes of preparing a section 137 report—that is, 'anything that you see, experience, read, or are told that causes you to believe that something is true or has really happened' (Collins Dictionary).

It is well established that an administrative decision maker can have regard to a wide range of materials in making a decision. This is particularly so where the Veterans' Review Board itself is not bound by the rules of evidence (see section 138 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986). Therefore, it is appropriate that the Secretary adopts a broad interpretation of 'evidence' when preparing a report under section 137 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act1986. This helps ensure that all relevant material is provided for the Veterans' Review Board's consideration when it is undertaking a review.

As Petition EN3399 notes, the Repatriation Commission, rather than the Secretary, also has the power under section 138(2) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to make available to the Veterans' Review Board statements of principles applied by the Repatriation Commission in determining and reviewing claims, along with any other material the Repatriation Commission considers may be of assistance to the Veterans' Review Board in relation to its review. The reference to 'other material' in section 138(2)(b) extends beyond 'evidence' relating to a particular claim. This would include, amongst other things, policy documents and guidance materials of general relevance, rather than material that is relevant only to a specific claim. The permissive rather than mandatory powers afforded to the Repatriation Commission under section 138(2) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 cannot be taken to limit what the Secretary is required to do under section 137.

It is in the interests of veterans that all relevant material is provided to the Veterans' Review Board at the earliest opportunity, to help the Veterans' Review Board achieve its statutory objective of providing a mechanism of review that is 'fair, just, economical, informal and quick'. Accordingly, there are no plans to require the Secretary to adopt a narrow or restrictive interpretation of 'evidence' for the purposes of preparing a report under section 137 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.
Thank you for bringing the concerns set out in Petition number EN3399 to my attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Gee
Veterans
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning Petition No EN3423 seeking amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to require the Repatriation Medical Authority to amend the definition of 'tooth wear' in the Statement of Principles for Tooth Wear (Nos 52 and 53 of 2017) so any depletion of the enamel of a tooth is deemed to be an 'injury' within section 50 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and compensable under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 or the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004.

The Repatriation Medical Authority has determined a comprehensive set of Statements of Principles dealing with injury or disease relating to the teeth and gums including Tooth Wear, Loss of Teeth (Nos 124 and 125 of 2015), Dental Caries (Nos 122 and 123 of 2015), Dental Malocclusion (Nos 19 and 20 of 2019), as well as the associated diseases such as Periodontitis (Nos 47 and 48 of 2013), Periodontal Abscess (Nos 49 and 50 of 2013), Bruxism (Nos 91 and 92 of 2016), Dental Pulp and Periapical Disease (Nos 99 and 100 of 2021) and Gingivitis (Nos 45 and 46 of 2013).

The factors in these Statements of Principles connect these medical conditions, be they injuries or diseases, with the circumstances of military service given the tests set out in section 1968(14) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 that effectively require service to be a direct or contributory cause in order for a factor to be 'related to service'.

It is correct that the definition of tooth wear in those Statements of Principles excludes 'mild tooth wear which is confined to the enamel'. However, loss of tooth enamel is incorporated into other Statements of Principles in manner consistent with the statutory requirements. For example, the Statements of Principles for dental caries deals with tooth decay including loss of enamel and provides factors linking decay with military service including being 'exposed to fermentable dietary carbohydrates'. That factor links sugars or heat-processed starch which can be converted by oral bacteria to acids to loss of enamel.

By requiring any change in tooth enamel occurring during service to be considered as an injury related to service, the petitioner's proposed change would effectively abolish any limitations on the service relationship as outlined in section 1968(14) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. It would mean a mere temporal link between service and injury would result in compensation for the disease or injury without there being any direct or contributory cause.

The current Statement of Principles system has wide support amongst the veteran community and its use is expanding. The Productivity Commission in its review of veterans' compensation, A Better Way to Support Veterans, noted that support for that system and endorsed it as 'robust and effective' concluding that:-
"it promotes consistency, predictability and transparency and draws a clear line between accepted and non-accepted conditions, based on sound medical scientific evidence". [p.349]

Under an arrangement with the Australian Government, the Statements of Principles are now specifically referred to in the New Zealand Veterans' Support Act 2014 and otherwise are used extensively by the Canadian Veterans Review and Appeal Board.
In my view the petitioner's complaint provides no basis for its alteration. Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Gee
Veterans
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021 regarding Petition number EN3494, which requests the House to initiate processes to return section 137(1) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to what is stated to be its statutory intent—that is, to ensure the Secretary of the Department of Veterans' Affairs (OVA) prepares section 137 reports and the Repatriation Commission ceases the practice of conducting internal reviews of decisions under section 31 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 until after it has received a section 148 notice from the Veterans' Review Board.

The Petition refers to a Repatriation Commission guideline which sets out a strategy for the extended use of the internal review powers under section 31 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, to examine all the available evidence on file when Veterans' Review Board appeals are received and to undertake a review on own motion wherever possible. If that matter cannot be resolved at that early stage, the section 137 report would be prepared and the matter would proceed to the Veterans' Review Board for its review.

Under section 31 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, the Repatriation Commission (or its delegate) may, in its discretion, review a decision at any time before the Veterans' Review Board determines the outcome of an appeal. The relevant Repatriation Commission Guideline sets out the following strategy for the extended use of section 31 review powers:
to examine all the available evidence on file in relation to Veterans' Review Board appeals and conduct a section 31 review wherever possible or prepare a section 137 report within 42 days,
to conduct section 31 reviews upon request by a veteran, and

to make appropriate contact with the veteran or their representative where a specific request for review under section 31 has been made, to address such matters as explanation of the original decision, clarify the basis of the request for section 31 review and allow for further evidence to be presented.

The stated aim of the strategy is to make the right decisions at the primary level (including section 31 review) and reduce the flow of applications to the Veterans' Review Board and Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This is intended to ensure if a review can positively resolve a claim prior to a Veterans' Review Board hearing this be done in order to reduce the impost on the veteran. This Repatriation Commission Guideline was introduced at the request of a number of Ex-Service organisations who consider this to be a positive and beneficial approach for veterans.

Under section 137, the Secretary must arrange for a report to be prepared which refers to the evidence that is under the control of OVA that is relevant to the Veterans' Review Board's review of a Repatriation Commission decision. This process runs in tandem with the Repatriation Commission's consideration of whether a review of the decision should be undertaken under section 31 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. The Repatriation Commission Guideline is concerned with the conduct of the section 31 review and does not state the Repatriation Commission will prepare the section 137 report.

Section 148 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 provides once relevant documents are provided to the Veterans' Review Board for the purposes of its review, the Principal Member (of the Veterans' Review Board) must issue a notice to both the veteran and the Repatriation Commission advising a review will be undertaken and asking them to confirm whether they wish to appear at a hearing in relation to the review, either in person or by way of a representative. This does not impact on the Repatriation Commission's power to undertake its own review under section 31 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. As noted above, the Repatriation Commission is entitled to do so any time before the Veterans' Review Board makes a decision in relation to the appeal.

Where claims are capable of being resolved, it is in the interests of veterans this occurs at the earliest possible stage. There are therefore no plans to limit the current review powers of the Repatriation Commission under section 31 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.
Thank you for bringing the concerns set out in Petition number EN3494 to my attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Gee
International Relations
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email regarding Australia's funding to multilateral organisations.

I agree that it is important that the UN and other multilateral institutions deliver for Australians. This is why we continue to advocate for improved performance of multilateral organisations and to protect and promote rules, standards and values that benefit our constituents.

The pandemic has highlighted the major role that international institutions play in coordinating a global response to a global problem, and shows that our international order is as important as ever. It has exposed the serious consequences Australia faces, should we fail to ensure these institutions are fit for purpose, accountable to member states, and free from undue influence.

Australia's contributions to multilateral organisations, including the UN agencies, means they can deliver outcomes vital to Australia's national interests, contributing to security and prosperity in our region, and for Australia.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne(Petition No. EN3544)
Iran
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter regarding the petition (EN3550) for an international Commission of Inquiry into the 1988 execution of Iranian political prisoners.
Iran's human rights record has been a longstanding and serious concern for Australia, and we regularly raise these concerns directly with Iran, and in multilateral fora.

In addition to routinely co-sponsoring the annual UN General Assembly (UNGA) resolution on the situation of human rights in Iran, Australia frequently condemns Iran's continued use of the death penalty, most recently in our statement to the UNGA on 25 October 2021 and to the UN Human Rights Council on 10 March 2021. Australian officials also make direct representations to the Iranian Government regarding executions, including on 11 and 26 November 2021 in Canberra, and 9 January 2022 in Tehran.

Australia opposes the death penalty in every circumstance, and reports of the events in 1988 are deeply disturbing. We will continue to follow closely the human rights situation in Iran and voice our concerns as appropriate.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Waste Management and Recycling
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition (EN3558) 'Ban the production and use of all non-recyclable and new plastics in Australia—tackling plastic pollution at its sources'.

The Australian Government takes the issue of plastic waste and its impacts on the environment very seriously. Our National Waste Policy Action Plan includes seven ambitious national targets to make Australia a world leader in resource management and recovery. Under the Plan, we are acting on plastic waste by banning exports of unprocessed plastic waste and phasing-out problematic and unnecessary plastics through sustainable design, innovation or the introduction of sustainable alternatives by 2025.
The government also launched the nation's first National Plastics Plan on 4 March 2021.

We are attacking the plastic problem on five key fronts: legislation, investment, industry targets, research and development and community education. You can read more about the Plan at environment.gov.au/plastics-plan.

Following the commitments in the National Waste Policy Action Plan and National Plastics Plan, on 15 April 2021, Australian Environment Ministers identified eight 'problematic and unnecessary' plastic product types for industry to phase out nationally by 2025 (or sooner in some cases). These are lightweight plastic bags, plastic products misleadingly termed as 'degradable', plastic straws, plastic bowls and plates, plastic utensils and stirrers, expanded polystyrene, commonly known as EPS, consumer food containers (e.g. cups and clamshells), EPS consumer goods packaging (loose fill and moulded) and microbeads in personal health care products. For example, 99.3 per cent of plastic microbeads and products containing them have been successfully removed from rinse off cosmetic, personal care and cleaning products.

State and territory governments are responsible for legislating the phase out of problematic single use plastics or regulating specific products. The Australian Government continues to work with the jurisdictions to harmonise phaseouts where possible, and will consider options to expand the scope of these product types in the future.

To help reduce the production of further plastic waste, the government is supporting the Australian Packaging Covenant Organisation's work with industry to deliver the 2025 National Packaging Targets. The Targets will drive improved product design to ensure 100 per cent of packaging in Australia is recyclable, reusable, or compostable and 70 per cent of plastic packaging is recycled or composted by 2025 or earlier.

As the waste export ban is phased in, Australia must also shift to recycling 645,000 tonnes each year, of waste plastic, paper, glass and tyres domestically. Additional recycling infrastructure is required to achieve this. We are driving a $1 billion transformation of our waste and recycling industry. The government's $280 million Recycling Modernisation Fund (RMF) is supercharging investment in recycling infrastructure so that Australia can take responsibility for its own waste, including plastic waste.

The government is delivering the RMF in partnership with states and territories and industry and it is on track to leverage over $1 billion in new investment in Australia's recycling industry. We have recently expanded the RMF by $60 million to target state of the art advanced and innovative plastic recycling technology for hard-to-recycle plastics. This will help increase the collection of plastics for recycling, including soft plastics, boost plastic recycling rates and increase the availability of recycled plastics for reuse in plastic products, including in food grade packaging. This will help us reduce our use of new plastics and will drive progress on the National Packaging Targets.

Australian consumers also play an important role in preventing plastic pollution, which is why the government is supporting the Australasian Recycling label (ARL). The ARL can be found on many supermarket products and packaging, provides clear and easy-to-understand instructions on how to correctly dispose of all parts of a product's packaging. By looking out for the ARL on packaging, consumers can better understand whether the products they are buying are recyclable, non-recyclable or whether they need to take extra steps to make sure the item is recycled. In May 2021 the government announced a 2021-2022 budget commitment of $5 million to support 20,000 small-to-medium enterprise businesses to adopt the ARL.

In addition to our domestic actions on plastic waste, the government recognises that an urgent global response is needed to reduce and eliminate the discharge of plastic pollution into our environment. That is why at the resumed fifth session of the United Nations Environment Assembly, Australia supported the adoption of a resolution to launch negotiations on a new international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution.

I hope this serves to demonstrate that tackling plastic pollution is a priority for the government. We are undertaking a comprehensive and ambitious program to address this significant national challenge in close collaboration with industry and state and territory governments.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Waste Reduction and Environmental Management, Mr Evans
Employment
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 14 February 2022 to the Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, the Hon Michaelia Cash MP, referring petition EN3566, which asks for body modifications to be made a protected attribute under Commonwealth workplace laws.

As the petition states, under the Fair Work Act 2009, physical appearance is not a protected attribute and employers can implement dress codes and other workplace policies governing physical appearance, including tattoos, piercings and other body modifications. However, such policies must be reasonable, and must not result in unfair treatment or discrimination on the basis of a protected attribute (e.g. race, colour, sex, sexual orientation or age). Prospective employees should also have the policy explained to them during the recruitment process. This approach is consistent with Commonwealth anti-discrimination laws, which don't protect body modifications.

There may also be legitimate health and safety concerns that are relevant to the requirements of the job, and which an employer must consider. However, this will depend on the type of job and body modification.

Noting the above, the Government is of the view that the existing legislative framework strikes an appropriate balance between protecting employers' rights to make decisions about the appearance of employees who work at and represent their business, and the protection of employees from discrimination.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Michaelia Cash
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 14 February 2022 to the Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Karen Andrews MP concerning Petition EN3567 asking, among other issues for the House to continue to recognise COVID-19 vaccines approved overseas for entry into Australia. Minister Andrews has asked me to respond as responsibility for COVID-19 vaccine recognition falls within my Portfolio. I regret the delay in responding.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), part of my Department, supports the Australian Government's objective of opening international borders by implementing an independent risk-based approach to COVID-19 vaccine recognition that is intended to protect the community in Australia. Vaccine recognition is based on an assessment of available scientific evidence regarding COVID-19 vaccines that have been used overseas and whether they provide a level of protection against infection and severe disease that is comparable to the protection provided by the COVID-19 vaccines that have been approved for use in Australia.

The TGA currently recognises ten COVID-19 vaccines, including those approved for marketing in Australia. This includes the eight vaccines that have been recognised by the World Health Organization (WHO) under its Emergency Usage Listing, as well as two-dose Sputnik V. The list of vaccines that are recognised by the TGA is comparable with those recognised as conferring full vaccination status for entry into Canada, the United States of America, the United Kingdom and New Zealand.

The TGA will continue to assess COVID-19 vaccines that have been used overseas in order to recognise new products when there is data to demonstrate that they provide adequate protection from COVID-19. This process is dependent on the availability of studies in the international peer-reviewed literature, whether manufacturers are able to provide additional data, and whether agencies such as the WHO can share their assessments. Unfortunately, there is a paucity of published or otherwise available studies for vaccines which have not been widely used.

The vaccination status of incoming travellers is only one part of Australia's border protection measures. People can travel to Australia regardless of their vaccination status, with the proviso that they may have to follow additional COVID-19 protection measures for a short time following their arrival.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Parliamentarians
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter of 14 February requesting a response to petition EN3574 relating to a proposal to score speeches made in the House of Representatives on the basis of relevance and other criteria.

Under the standing orders, during most debates Members must speak only on the subject matter of a question under discussion (standing order 76). A requirement for 'direct relevance' applies to answers to questions without notice (standing order 104). As Speaker, I am regularly called on to rule on relevance from the Chair. While it can be a complex task requiring consideration of the subject, the context and relevant precedents, I believe it is appropriate to address questions of relevance at the time they arise. These rulings guide Members who were not being relevant to return to the matter at hand if they continue to speak.

It is open to anyone to form their own assessment of what Members say in the House. The proceedings of parliament are made publicly available in a variety of formats. The Hansard record of parliamentary debates is published after each sitting, along with the Votes and Proceedings. Members of the public may also view proceedings live or play them back through the www.aph.gov.au/Watch_Read_Listen web page. Proceedings of both Houses are broadcast on the radio and on television in accordance with the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act 1946. Further, people may also watch the House and the Federation Chamber from the public galleries, public health considerations permitting. The parliament also facilitates media access to proceedings. Through these different avenues, Members' contributions can be considered by members of the public. Members are ultimately accountable to their constituents, with their performance assessed at the ballot box.

For these reasons, I do not consider that it is appropriate or necessary to establish the type of 'scoring' system requested by the petitioners as a formal mechanism of the House. Such a system could also be complex for the House to administer and may be open to real or perceived partisanship or political point-scoring. As I outline above, anyone can watch, listen to or read the proceedings of parliament and examine Members' speeches and other contributions. Indeed, I encourage them to do so.
Yours sincerely
from the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Wallace
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition number EN3577 requesting funding and support to make the COVAX-19 vaccine available to the Australian public. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government remains committed to providing access to free and effective COVID-19 vaccines to everyone living in Australia. To support this aim, the Government has invested in a diverse portfolio of COVID-19 vaccines that use a variety of technical platforms, securing supply for all eligible populations within Australia.

The safety of the Australian population has always been the highest priority of the Government. It is working closely with the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), who has responsibility for formally assessing the safety, quality and efficacy of medicines, including vaccines, prior to their approval for use in Australia. All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes, after being tested in large clinical trials on thousands of people. The process for application and approval ofCOVID-19 vaccines can be found on the TGA website at: www.tga.gov.au/covid-19-vaccine-approval-process.

The TGA granted provisional determination to Vaxine Pty Ltd for their COVAX-19 COVID-19 vaccine on 15 December 2021. Provisional Determination is the first step in the process that enables the sponsor to apply to the TGA for provisional registration in the
Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG). As for all provisional determinations, it is for six months and so will expire in mid-June 2022.

Provisional determination does not mean that an application has or will be made, or that the vaccine will be provisionally approved for inclusion in the ARTG. Registration and supply in Australia will only commence should the vaccine be approved as safe and effective by the TGA.

Vaxine Pty Ltd, the company developing Flinders University's COVID-19 vaccine candidate 'COVAX-19®' was funded $1 million through the Government's Biomedical Translation Bridge Program, an initiative of the Medical Research Future Fund. Vaxine Pty Ltd has not yet submitted an application for provisional registration. However, a limited amount of preliminary clinical data was submitted to the TGA to support the provisional determination application.

From publicly available information, it appears that the COVAX-19 vaccine has been tested in Phase II and III clinical trials in Iran in collaboration with Iranian biotechnology company CinnaGen. Details of the clinical trials underway for the COVAX-19 vaccine can be found on the COVID-19 vaccine tracker at: www.covid19.trackvaccines.org/vaccines/8.

The TGA has not been provided with a copy of the submission made to the Iranian regulator and as the Iranian regulator is not a member of the International Coalition of Medicines Regulatory Agencies, we have very little information on Iranian regulatory requirements for these products.

For individuals looking to be vaccinated with a more traditional, protein-based vaccine option, the Novavax vaccine is now available for administration in Australia to those aged 18 years and over following approval by the TGA and recommendation by the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI).

The Novavax vaccine is a protein subunit vaccine. Protein vaccines use a non-infectious component found on the surface of the virus and are manufactured in cells in a laboratory. After vaccination, immune cells recognise the vaccine protein as foreign and launch an immune response against it. The vaccine was subject to the same rigorous TGA assessment and approval process, with ATAGI noting it was been demonstrated to be highly effective in preventing symptomatic COVID-19 in adults.

The Government has also finalised an agreement with global pharmaceutical company Moderna that secures the production of up to 100 million Australian made messenger ribonucleic acid (mRNA) doses every year and hundreds of manufacturing jobs too.

The strategic partnership will ensure Australia can meet its ongoing COVID-19 vaccine needs, and any other new and innovative respiratory mRNA vaccines. It will also make Australia a critical regional hub for mRNA technology development and production, bolstering our local biotechnology sector.

It is important for Australians to have access to credible and timely information about COVID-19 vaccines. I strongly encourage everyone to stay up to date on all news and announcements, by regularly checking my Department's website 1;1t: www.health.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition c on COVID-19 vaccination. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.
At the same time, the Government's position on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia. Everyone maintains the option to choose.

However, the Government has made it mandatory for those working in residential aged care to receive a COVID-19 vaccination, which was advised by the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee and accepted by the National Cabinet. This is enforced through state and territory public-health orders, effective 17 September 2021.

As the COVID-19 pandemic is a public health emergency, states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public health, are managing the pandemic in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice. States and territories have issued public health orders which require COVID-19 vaccination for people in high-risk workplaces and sectors, and for some community activities. Further information about public health orders may be found on state or territory government websites.

All vaccines are thoroughly tested for safety before they are approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) for use in Australia. The TGA is part of my Department, and is responsible for regulating therapeutic goods, including prescription medicines, vaccines, sunscreens, vitamins and minerals, medical devices, blood and blood products.
Testing includes carefully analysing clinical trial data, ingredients, chemistry, manufacturing, and other factors. Even after an individual receives a vaccine, it is still monitored for safety.

If an individual has any questions about vaccination they should talk to their doctor, nurse, or other healthcare professional. Their healthcare professional can then give feedback to the TGA about any side effects, even if they are minor. This will help the regulator in overseeing the safety of vaccines. In the unlikely event that a safety risk develops, the TGA will inform healthcare providers, the community, and the Government as soon as possible.

The Petitions Committee can be assured that the Government, along with the states and territories, is taking an evidence-based approach to COVID-19 and is committed to protecting the health of Australians.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination

I refer to your correspondence concerning petition number EN3586 requesting financial support to ensure availability of the COVAX-19 vaccine in Australia. I regret the delay in responding.
