It is important for Australians to have access to credible and timely information about COVID-19 vaccines. I strongly encourage everyone to stay up to date on all news and announcements, by regularly checking my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Social Media
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter dated 14 February 2022, on behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions, concerning Petition EN3599—requesting the implementation of a Bill requiring media and social media platforms to state where an individual's appearance had been digitally altered.

The Australian Government understand the concerns raised in the petition regarding the impact digitally altered images can have on the health and wellbeing of vulnerable Australians, particularly impressionable young people.

The eSafety website www.esafety.gov.au provides a wide range of online safety advice and education materials including resources that cover media literacy, distinguishing real imagery from altered imagery and ways to minimise your exposure and risk of body image issues.

A range of resources are also available through the eSafety parents and carers portal, to educate parents about potential online risks and how to help their children manage negative situations online. The portal can be found at www.esafety.gov.au/parents.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of this petition to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities & the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Migration
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022, enclosing Petition EN3600 with 3 signatures, regarding the Australian Government's immigration policies.

Australia has a universal, non-discriminatory visa system, which focuses on the contribution a person can make to Australia rather than their ethnicity, gender, race, nationality or religious beliefs. Australia enjoys high levels of social cohesion and broad public support for its migration programs and this is, in part based on confidence in well-managed non-discriminatory migration.
Each application for migration to Australia is assessed on its merits against Australian law set out in the Migration Act 1958 and Migration Regulations 1994.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3600 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
COVID-19: Schools
Dear Chair
I refer to correspondence of 14 February 2022 regarding Petition Number EN3602.

The Australian Government recognises that the past 2 years have been hard for all Australians, especially students. They have missed out on some of the simple joys of growing up-school camps, team sports and playground friendships. The Government holds the position that it is vital that all students continue to engage with a high-quality education and progress through their year levels throughout the COVID-19 pandemic. The Government is committed to making sure our schools are safe places for students to learn with investments in school upgrades and mental health that will make sure every student can get back on track and benefit from a world class education.

The Government has announced a $240 million School Upgrade Fund. This will provide $40 million for Australian schools, government and non-government, with access to grants in 2022 to improve air quality with measures such as better ventilation, building more outdoor classrooms, replacing boarded-up windows and doors, and buying air purifiers as they move to COVID-normal settings. Secondly, in 2023, $200 million will be provided to states and territories for government schools for new buildings, facilities and refurbishments.

Additionally, government and non-government schools can access Commonwealth recurrent funding. This can be used for the purchase of capital equipment, construction, or capital improvements to a school-such as ventilation and air quality monitoring systems.

While the Australian Government takes a leadership role in matters of national education policy, state and territory governments and non-government education authorities are responsible for managing and making operational decisions for their schools. Decisions regarding the response to COVID-19 in the schooling sector continue to be informed by expert, national, and state-based public health advice. More broadly, states and territories have already put in place a range of initiatives to support well-ventilated classrooms, which consider their differing local circumstances.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Clare
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair

I refer to correspondence to the former Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Karen Andrews MP, regarding Petition EN3619 requesting that the House consider recognising the Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine administered overseas to people over 60 years of age for entry into Australia. That correspondence was referred to the former Minister for Health, the Hon Greg Hunt as responsibility for COVID-19 vaccine recognition falls within the Health Portfolio. I am responding as the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), part of the Department of Health, has continued to conduct assessments of information regarding COVID 19 vaccines that have been used globally as it has become available. This information helps inform decisions at Australia's international border with respect to incoming travellers, and this work continues to be an important element in allowing Australia to re-open its international borders.

In general, COVID-19 vaccines are recognised for the purpose of inbound travel if they provide comparable protection against infection and severe infection/hospitalisation to those COVID-19 vaccines approved and used in Australia. Ideally, demonstrated efficacy against infection should be over 65%, and efficacy against severe infection/hospitalisation should be over 85%.

TGA's initial assessment of data regarding BBIBP-CorV (Sinopharm) vaccine found the maximum severe infection/hospitalisation rate was 79% (6% lower than the ideal minimum of 85%), with estimates from one large study being even lower. The World Health Organization also noted the limitations of the scientific information regarding efficacy for those over 60 years of age in relation to the Sinopharm vaccine.
As a result of TGA's initial assessment, in November 2021, the TGA recognised the
Sinopharm vaccine for the purposes of inbound travel for people under 60 years of age because of the lower absolute risk of severe infection/hospitalisation in younger people.
This was a risk-based decision taking into account the fact that age is a major factor affecting progression to severe disease with COVID-19 infection.

The TGA has continued to monitor the scientific literature, including results of real-world evidence and ongoing trials assessing the effectiveness of the Sinopharm vaccine, and as a result of recently published data on 10 May 2022, amended its decision and removed the age limit (e.g. <60 years of age).
This decision means the Sinopharm vaccine is a recognised vaccine for the purposes of inbound travel for travellers of all ages.
The TGA's assessment of this additional data can be found on the TGA's website at www.tga.gov.au using the search term 'international vaccine recognition'.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition number EN3625 regarding vaccination for children aged 5 to 12 years. I regret the delay in responding.

People eligible for vaccination have been identified considering the current supply of vaccines and public health, medical and epidemiological evidence on who would be most at risk of contracting COVID-19, or of serious illness if they contracted COVID-19.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration {TGA) completes a full and thorough assessment of COVID-19 vaccines and will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine, if it is found to be safe and effective. No part of the process has been rushed, and there was no emergency authorisation granted.

All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes including clinical trials. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials test for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and/or disease.

The TGA requires robust scientific data before supporting a vaccine candidate and will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is found to be safe and effective, following its complete assessment of data.

The TGA is also part of a network of international regulators that meet regularly to discuss the development of COVID-19 vaccines. This information, together with the potential to use already established work-sharing arrangements and collaboration with other international regulators, is assisting the TGA to expedite the evaluation of any new vaccines without compromising on strict standards of safety, quality and effectiveness.

COVID-19 vaccination in the 5 to 11-year-old age group commenced on 10 January 2022, with two vaccine options recommended for children under the age of 12. The paediatric Pfizer vaccine is recommended by the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation for 5 to 11-year-olds and the Moderna vaccine is recommended for 6 to 11-year-olds. Both vaccines have been subject to the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval process and continue to provide free, effective protection for children in this age group, their families and communities.

Vaccination is the best way to help prevent children from getting sick, particularly those at greater risk from underlying medical conditions. Vaccination may also give indirect benefits to children by preventing disruptions to school and extracurricular activities and reducing the spread of the virus through the community. Further information is available at: www.health.gov.au using the search term 'is it true'.

The Standing Committee on Petitions can be assured that the Australian Government, along with the states and territories, is taking an evidence-based approach to COVID-19 and is committed to protecting the health of Australians.
Thank you for bringing the constituents' concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Diwali
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter dated 14 February 2022 regarding Petition Ministerial Referral (EN3626)—declaring Diwali as a public holiday.
The Australian Government recognises the cultural significance of Diwali, the annual Festival of Light, as a special celebration for people of many faiths.

Australia is one of the most successful multicultural societies in the world. We have achieved this success by welcoming and integrating people from many cultures from all parts of the world. Our diversity has played an important role in our prosperity, enriching Australia and deepening our connections with the region and wider world.

The celebration of Diwali in many forms both, publicly and privately across Australia, demonstrates the importance of freedom of faith and freedom of association in Australia. The Australian Government is committed to protecting these values, and ensuring that people in Australia can continue to come together to celebrate events like Diwali into the future.

The declaration of public holidays is the responsibility of the states and territories. Where a public holiday has been recognised nationally this has been agreed by the National Cabinet. The proclamation of 'days of national observance' by the Governor-General is just one of a number of ways to promote the observation of days of celebration or commemoration.

National days and culturally significant events may be observed without a proclamation or intervention by the Australian Government. A number of days throughout the year have gained community acceptance as the dates on which particular events are celebrated or commemorated. Mothers' Day and Harmony Day are among the many examples of days throughout the year that have gained community acceptance as the dates on which particular events are celebrated or commemorated, without government involvement.
Thank you again for writing to me on this important matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Prime Minister, Mr Morrison
Disability Services
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 14 February 2022 on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions concerning petition number EN3627.

Australia's health system is one of the best in the world and strives to provide safe and affordable high quality care for every Australian. In keeping with this, the Australian Government is committed to ensuring all Australians are able to access high quality, affordable health care by providing both free and subsidised healthcare services.

The Government believes a mixed model of private and public health services is integral to the provision of these services. All Australian residents, regardless of whether they hold private health insurance, are eligible to be treated free of charge as public patients under the universal health system, Medicare.

Australian private health insurers are required to offer community-rated health insurance. Community rating ensures the premium paid by consumers for a private health insurance policy does not vary based on health status, age, or whether the person has a disability. This prevents private health insurers from discriminating between people, including those who may require more services and are more vulnerable to health expenses.

The Government maintains its commitment to providing access to safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines to everyone in Australia. Vaccination against COVID-19 is one of the most effective ways to reduce severe illness and death from infection, however, individuals maintain the option to choose to vaccinate.

Alongside the rollout of COVID-19 vaccines, the Government has implemented a claims scheme for people who suffer a moderate to significant impact following an adverse reaction to a Therapeutic Goods Administration approved COVID-19 vaccine. Information about the scheme, including advice on how to claim is available on my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au by searching for 'COVID-19 vaccine claims scheme'.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Australian Sign Language
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 to the Minister for Education and Youth, regarding Petition EN3636 that was presented to the House of Representatives on the teaching of Auslan in Australian schools. As the Acting Minister for Education and Youth, your correspondence has been provided to me for response.
The petition requests that the House of Representatives make Auslan available early on in public schools across Australia and that it encourages private schools to do the same.
The Australian Government plays a leadership role and provides funding for areas of national educational importance; however it does not have a direct role in the operation of schools.

Decisions relating to the teaching and availability of Auslan as a language of formal study in schools are a matter for the State and Territory education authorities, and, in some cases, individual schools.

The Government acknowledges the importance of providing young Australians with the opportunity to learn Auslan at school. The addition of Auslan to the Foundation—Year 10 Australian Curriculum (the Curriculum) in 2016 represented a significant achievement to this end, in systematising provision in Australian schools, serving both deaf and hearing student populations, and rightfully acknowledging the place of Auslan in Australian society.

Further information about Auslan's place in the nationally agreed curriculum, which sets the expectations for what all young Australians across the country should be taught regardless of where they live or their background, is available at www.australiancurriculum.edu.au/f-10-curriculum/languages/auslan.

More broadly, the Government has funded the Australian Federation of Modem Languages Teachers Associations (AFMLTA) to undertake research to inform the development of recommendations for increasing participation in languages learning in Australian schools. As part of this research, the AFMLTA conducted a national stakeholder forum in mid-2021.

This was followed by a series of focus groups with language teachers across Australia to discuss jurisdiction-specific issues, with one focus group dedicated to Auslan. Initial feedback indicates increased interest in Learning Auslan as an additional language and the importance of qualified and experienced teachers, noting the final research report will be delivered in mid-2022. The Government will consider these recommendations and approp1iate next steps once the final report is delivered. Further information on the project is available at www.afmlta.asn.au.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Acting Minister for Education and Youth, Mr Robert
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition number EN3646 requesting a fast track of the Novavax vaccine. I regret the delay in responding.

The safety of the Australian population has always been the Australian Government's highest priority. For this reason, decisions regarding COVID-19 vaccines have been, and continue to be, based on the expert medical advice of the both the Therapeutic Goods Administration {TGA) and the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI).

I am pleased to confirm that Australians aged 18 years and over now have access to the Novavax COVID-19 vaccine after the Government accepted advice from ATAGI that it be included in the rollout program. The recommendations from ATAGI follow Australia's medicines regulator, the TGA, provisionally approving the Novavax vaccine for use in Australia. ATAGI has recommended the Novavax vaccine be given in two doses, at least three weeks apart.

Administration of the vaccine began in the week of 21 February 2022 following batch testing. Australians can access a Novavax vaccine through general practices, community pharmacies, Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Services, Commonwealth vaccination centres, and state and territory clinics.

Novavax is a protein subunit vaccine. Protein vaccines use a non-infectious component found on the surface of the virus and are manufactured in cells in a laboratory. After vaccination, immune cells recognise the vaccine protein as foreign and launch an immune response against it. This vaccine provides a further option to those who may have been hesitant to use the current available options.

ATAGI notes that the vaccine has been demonstrated to be highly effective in preventing symptomatic COVID-19 in adults. It can also be administered to pregnant and breastfeeding women and for people who are severely immunocompromised, who are recommended to receive three doses for their primary course of vaccination.
The ATAGI advises that Novavax can also be used as a booster dose if no other COVID-19 vaccine brand is suitable for that individual.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Centrelink
Dear Mr O'Dowd

I refer to your correspondence and petition with 144 signatures, concerning the closure of Services Australia's (the Agency's) Benalla Visiting Service and the request for the Minister for Government Services to review this decision and to re-open the Benalla Centrelink Office as a matter of urgency.

The Benalla Visiting Service was suspended on 6 April 2020, due to COVID-19 restrictions, and did not reopen. The Visiting Service transitioned to an Agent service from 28 June 2021 located at 85 Nunn Street, Benalla, Victoria.

Since the Agent Service opened, the Benalla community has had reliable and consistent access to Centrelink, Medicare and Child Support services. The locally based Agent is open Monday to Friday from 9.30am to 3.30pm, offering a face-to-face service for 30 hours a week, up from 24 hours a week offered through the visiting service.

Agents are provided with extensive training to ensure they can support customers to conduct their business with the Agency. Agents offer access to services such as phones, printing and internet enabled computers, and help customers register for and use digital self-serve channels, including myGov. Free Wi-Fi is available for community members to complete their government business online. The Agent service can also connect local residents with more complex enquiries directly to an Agency staff member via a dedicated phone line.

Benalla residents continue to have access to the Wangaratta Service Centre at 25 Faithfull Street, Wangaratta where they can choose to book an appointment at a time suitable to them. Booking an appointment means customers won't need to wait in a queue. These appointments can also be completed by telephone, reducing the need to travel to Wangaratta Service Centre and wait for assistance. Customers can book these services by telephoning the Agency's regular payment lines. The agency's Mobile Service Centre continues to visit Benalla annually.

Since July 2021, the staff at the Benalla Agent have worked closely with the staff at the Wangaratta Service Centre to coordinate additional and specialised support for vulnerable customers where required. The Benalla Agent promotes Appointment Based Servicing appointments as an option available to Benalla customers, and maintains strong links to the
Wangaratta Service Centre. This has enabled seamless referrals for vulnerable customers attending the Benalla Agent.

As a further support, the Agency is providing specialist staff to visit the Benalla community for the period 24 January 2022-15 April 2022. This was planned to commence earlier however due to COVID-19 restrictions, this was not possible. After this three-month period, the specialist servicing arrangements will be reviewed based on customer demand.

The Agency has also hosted two digital learning events in Benalla. The first event was held in July 2021 and the second in December 2021. These events provide the Agency the opportunity to talk to the community about self-managed services, build digital engagement, and promote the Agent Service. Community feedback from these events has been positive.
I acknowledge the concerns raised and would like to provide reassurance that the Agent Service, now in place in Benalla, will continue to assist customers to engage with the Agency.
I trust this information is of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Government Services, Senator Reynolds(Petition No. EN3647)
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 enclosing Petition EN3649 with 10 signatures, concerning international travel by Australian citizens to South Africa.

Since 1 November 2021, fully vaccinated Australians, permanent residents and their families have been able to leave Australia and return without needing an exemption. Further, on 15 December 2021, the international border was reopened to skilled workers, working holiday-makers, refugee, humanitarian, temporary and provisional family visa holders.

On 21 February 2022, Australia's international border was reopened to all remaining fully vaccinated visa holders. Unvaccinated visa holders continue to require a valid travel exemption to enter Australia, and all incoming travellers still need to comply with the quarantine and testing requirements of the state or territory of their arrival, and any other state or territory to which they plan to travel.

Australians can be reassured the Australian Government, as it has done throughout the pandemic, is acting on the best medical advice available to protect the community. The phased and careful reopening of Australia's international border has been achieved due to the discipline of Australians throughout the vaccine rollout and implementation of the National Plan. This has resulted in Australia having amongst the lowest fatalities in the world from COVID-19.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3649 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
China
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 enclosing Petition EN3654, with 31 signatures. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.
The Australian Government takes the threat of foreign interference seriously.
The Government has put a number of measures and legislative reforms in place to counter the threat. Some of those measures and legislative reforms are detailed below.

In 2018, the Government appointed the first National Counter Foreign Interference Coordinator to coordinate Australia's whole of government efforts to respond to acts of foreign interference. These relevantly included administering the Counter Foreign Interference Strategy, and enhancing engagement with culturally and linguistically diverse communities to strengthen their ability to challenge manipulation and coercion from foreign actors. The Coordinator is supported by the Counter Foreign Interference Coordination Centre.

In 2018, the Government also passed the National Security Legislation Amendment (Espionage and Foreign Interference) Act 2018(Cth) which introduced landmark foreign interference offences into the Criminal Code Act 1995 (Cth). These offences target those who engage in covert, deceptive or coercive conduct to interfere with the exercise of Australian political or democratic rights, or Australia's democratic systems and processes, on behalf of a foreign principal. These reforms are due to be reviewed by the Independent National Security Legislation Monitor. There will be an opportunity for interested Australians to engage in that review once it is formally established.

In 2018, the Australian Government also established the Electoral Integrity Assurance Taskforce (EIAT) to respond to threats to democracy through malicious cyber activity, physical means, electoral fraud, foreign interference and disinformation. The EIAT is focused on the upcoming Federal election, and will also be providing support to state, territory and local government elections across the country. The EIAT is made up of a number of Commonwealth agencies and is supported by the National Intelligence Community.

In 2019, the Government established a Counter Foreign Interference Taskforce (CFI Taskforce) that discovers, tracks and disrupts foreign interference in Australia. The CFI Taskforce is led by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, and has access to investigative functions and powers including telecommunications interception and surveillance. Part of the CFI Taskforce's remit includes responding
to allegations made by members of a diaspora community who fear that they may be being subject to interference by a foreign principal or its proxy.

The Government is in the process of reforming Australia's electronic surveillance legislative framework. In response to the findings of the Comprehensive Review of the Legal Framework of the National Intelligence Community, the Government has committed to repealing and replacing the existing framework currently divided across the Telecommunications (Interception and Access) Act 1979 (Cth), Surveillance Devices Act 2004 (Cth), and relevant parts of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979 (Cth) with one modernised, streamlined and consolidated Act. As part of this reform, the Government is considering existing prohibitions on surveillance activities in Australia.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 enclosing Petition EN3661 with 49 signatures, requesting consideration of quarantine-free travel arrangements with Malaysia and other south-east Asian countries with high levels of vaccination.

Australia's travel restriction policy has played a key foundational role underpinning management of COVID-19's impact on public health in Australia and was implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee. Global Talent Visa Program
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 enclosing Petition EN3662, with 11 signatures, concerning the Global Talent Visa application for Mr Ahmed Abdelwahed Saied Nasreldin.
The Global Talent Visa Program aims to attract individuals who can contribute to Australia's economy or global standing in priority sectors, and for whom there is not a more appropriate visa pathway.

Candidates must demonstrate an internationally recognised record of exceptional and outstanding achievement in one of the designated priority sectors. They must also demonstrate the ability to earn an income at the Fair Work High Income Threshold.

Applicants with exceptional and outstanding achievements include senior executives in internationally competitive organisations and those with commercially viable patents or internationally recognised awards.

I note that Mr Nasreldin has an Employer Nomination (subclass 186) visa application currently before the Department of Home Affairs, and that he holds a valid bridging visa to remain in Australia pending finalisation of that application. He is not required to leave Australia while that application is being processed.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3662 to my attention.

from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mr Hawke
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 enclosing petition EN3663 with six signatures, concerning the return of international students and temporary visa holders from overseas.
I recognise the significant impact the COVID-19 pandemic has had on many Australians and the lives and plans of visa holders, including international students wishing to study in Australia.

Australia's travel restriction policy has played a key foundational role underpinning management of COVID-19's impact on public health in Australia and was implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee. In accordance with the National Plan to Transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response, Australia is reopening its international border in a phased and careful way.
This graduated and safe reopening is a result of the success Australia and Australians have achieved through the vaccine rollout and in implementing the National Transition Plan.

As interested parties may be aware, from 15 December 2021, eligible visa holders, including international students, who are fully vaccinated in accordance with Australia's international border entry requirements became eligible to travel to Australia without seeking a travel exemption. Other eligible visa holders included Working Holiday maker visa holders, as well as other priority temporary visa cohorts.

Having supported the reunion of families, and Australia's economic recovery through the return to skilled and unskilled migration, and international students, Australia has now reopened to all remaining, fully vaccinated visa holders. From 21 February 2022, all visa holders who are fully vaccinated in accordance with Australia's international border entry requirements are able to travel to Australia without needing to obtain a travel exemption.

The changes from 21 February 2022 take into account the different levels of access that many countries have to vaccines, and the rate of the rollout of booster vaccines globally. The changes also take into account the evolving epidemiological situation in Australia, where our current vaccination rates are amongst the highest in the world.

Unvaccinated visa holders will still require a valid travel exemption to enter Australia, and all incoming travellers will still need to comply with the quarantine requirements of the state or territory of their arrival, and any other state or territory to which they plan to travel.
I recommend that interested parties keep up to date with the information and further detail available on the Department of Home Affairs website as well as other Australian Government websites.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3663 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 enclosing Petition EN3666 with 13 signatures, concerning the reopening of Australia's international border to travellers from countries currently experiencing significant viral outbreaks.
The petitioners requested the establishment of a triage system for travellers based on risk, as well as expressing specific concern for the wellbeing of Indigenous populations within Australia.

Australia's international border settings have played a key foundational role in underpinning the management of COVID-19's impact on public health in Australia. Australia has been opening in a staged and careful way. The path to reopening the international border has continually aligned with the National Plan to Transition Australia's National Response to the COVID-19 pandemic, and has always been based on the most up to date, expert, health advice. The Commonwealth has also worked closely with state and territory governments, who have established health controls and quarantine requirements in relation to post-border arrangements.

The Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) and associated subcommittees, the Infection Control Expert Group (ICEG) and the Communicable Diseases Network Australia (CDNA), provide expert medical advice to inform policies relating to public health measures, including Australia's international border settings. In addition, state and territory governments have put in place additional public health measures, consistent with health advice, to manage COVID-19 within the specific context of their jurisdiction.

I note that the petition refers to unequal levels of vaccination across Australia and that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, including those in remote communities, are at greater risk from COVID-19, particularly young people.

As at 7 March 2022, as reported in the Australian Immunisation Register (AIR), 83.6% of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people aged 16 and over have received their first dose, and 78.9% have received their second dose of a COVID-19 vaccine. While these figures are lower than the national average of 96.5% and 94.6% respectively, I note that Indigenous identification to the AIR is voluntary, so it only reflects people who have chosen to identify as Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander.

Recognising that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and those in remote communities are at greater risk from COVID-19, the Government has made it a priority to provide access to vaccines and resources on how communities can be kept safe. The Commonwealth continues to work with state and territory Governments to ensure that vulnerable cohorts are protected from COVID-19 and has made it clear that the greatest protection available is through vaccination.

As you are aware, on 7 February 2022, the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, announced that from 21 February 2022, all visa holders who are fully-vaccinated in accordance with Australia's international border entry requirements will be able to travel to Australia without needing a travel exemption.

All international arrivals are required to complete a Digital Passenger Declaration (DPD) before boarding a flight to Australia. The DPD collects information on the passenger's vaccination status, 14 day travel history, and a declaration that they have had a negative COVID-19 test prior to travelling to Australia. Information from passengers is provided to State and Territory health officials prior to arrival to enable triaging of passengers through post-border arrangements (including quarantine) based on risk.

On arrival in Australia, officers from the Australia Border Force (ABF) and the Department of Home Affairs undertake assurance activities to confirm the information provided by passengers on their DPD is genuine, such as checking evidence when medical contraindication to a COVID-19 vaccine is claimed as a reason for not being vaccinated. There is also the ability for all arrivals to receive a COVID-19 booster vaccine when in Australia if they choose to do so.

Once cleared by ABF officers to enter Australia, unvaccinated passengers (including those who have been vaccinated within the last seven days) are directed to state and territory health officials, and are subject to domestic health controls relevant to that jurisdiction's risk settings.

Passenger caps and quarantine requirements for unvaccinated travellers currently remain in effect, and all incoming travellers will still need to comply with the quarantine requirements of the state or territory of their arrival, and any other state or territory to which they plan to travel. This precaution continues to protect our health system's capacity to manage those seriously ill with COVID-19 while also supporting the provision of other essential health care. These requirements remain while supported by health advice.

Australia's economy is already rebounding back from the height of the pandemic, and future steps forward will further accelerate our recovery. While this change will make a significant impact across the entire economy, it will provide a particularly crucial boost to the tourism sector. However, all decisions regarding changes to border settings will be taken with health impacts as a primary concern.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3666 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Public Governance
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 14 February 2022 regarding Petition EN3668, which requests the establishment of a federal anti-corruption body. I welcome the opportunity to respond to this petition.

The Australian Government remains committed to establishing the Commonwealth Integrity Commission (CIC) to ensure our federal' integrity framework is as robust as possible. The Government committed ongoing funding to the CIC in the 2019-20 Budget. Total funding over the next four financial years from 2022-23 would be $168.3 million, noting the establishment of the CIC is subject to the passage of legislation.

The CIC will be an independent investigative agency with strong powers to target the most serious types of criminal conduct that threaten good public administration. The CIC will have broad jurisdiction over all Commonwealth entities, including law enforcement and public sector agencies, parliamentarians and their offices, higher education providers and research bodies. It will complement, rather than duplicate, other mechanisms which already exist to deal with issues of misconduct at the Commonwealth level.

This is a significant reform that must be implemented effectively, both because of the scale of the reform and because it is vital that Australians can have confidence that the CIC will operate fairly and effectively.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Michaelia Cash
Climate Change
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter of 14 February regarding petition EN3672 which asks the House to introduce legislation to implement a blanket advertising ban on internal combustion engine vehicles, modelled on the successful ban on tobacco advertising.

Advertising regulation in Australia is intended to strike a balance between legitimate commercial interests and appropriate community safeguards. The content of advertisements in Australia is subject to predominantly self-regulatory arrangements, underpinned by platform-neutral codes of practice developed by the Australian Association of National Advertisers (AANA), the advertising industry peak body, including the AANA Code of Ethics. The self-regulatory framework reflects that it is ultimately advertisers who bear the primary responsibility for the content of their advertisements. The advertising self-regulatory arrangements, including the handling of complaints, are administered by Ad Standards.

The Australian Government does not intend to implement a ban on advertising for internal combustion engine vehicles. Doing so could also prevent advertising for more fuel efficient vehicles including hybrid and plug-in hybrid vehicles and also prevent advertising of internal combustion engine vehicles with enhanced safety features.

The Australian Government is committed to enabling consumer choice for new vehicle and fuel technologies, ensuring Australian motorists can choose the vehicle that is right for them—be that petrol, diesel, hydrogen or electric powered.

The Australian Government will continue to partner with the private sector to create the enabling environment needed to support the increasing number of consumers choosing low emission vehicle technologies. The Future Fuels and Vehicles Strategy, released in November 2021, sets out how the Australian Government will support a technology-led approach to reducing transport emissions.

The Australian Government has now committed $2.1 billion to partner with industry to support uptake of low and zero emission vehicles. This includes the expanded $250 million Future Fuels Fund (up from $71.9 million), to support businesses to integrate new technology vehicles into their fleets, and deliver battery charging and refuelling infrastructure across capital cities and key regional centres, helping to improve motorist confidence.
Through the implementation of the Future Fuels and Vehicles Strategy, we are focusing on five priority initiatives that will make the most difference:
Electric vehicle charging and hydrogen refuelling infrastructure where it's needed;
Early focus on commercial fleets;
Improving information for motorists and fleets;
Integrating electric vehicles into the electricity grid; and
Supporting Australian innovation and manufacturing.

More information on how the Australian Government is enabling consumer choice for new vehicle and fuel technologies can be found at www.industry.gov.au/data-and- publications/future-fuels-and-vehicles-strategy
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, Mr Joyce

Citizenship
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 enclosing Petition EN3675 with 230 signatures, concerning a request to speed up the Citizenship application process, in particular, in Victoria. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.
The Australian Government is committed to maintaining public confidence in the Citizenship Program and ensuring a prosperous, secure and united Australia.
Citizenship test appointments have recommenced in all of the Department of Home Affairs' offices. Appointments have also recommenced in regional sites, managed by Services Australia.
Most applicants need to attend an appointment and sit the Australian citizenship test in-person. COVID-19 lockdowns in 2020 and 2021 disrupted test appointments in different locations.

The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on face-to-face client services, including appointments to sit the Australian citizenship test, means processing times are currently highly variable across the country, with applicants in Victoria waiting significantly longer for a test appointment, currently more than 12-months.

A key factor to the longer wait times in Victoria is due to public health orders, which caused the Department's office in Melbourne to be closed for a total of 56 weeks between March 2020 and January 2022. This was the longest service delivery disruption across all of the Department's offices.

To return to nationally consistent processing times, the Department has implemented a range of measures to deliver increased face-to-face client services and to provide the greatest possible processing efficiency while still maintaining COVIDSafe arrangements and the integrity of the Citizenship Program.

Where possible, the Department is offering extended operating hours to increase availability of test appointments, supported by additional client service counters in the largest processing locations, in particular, in Melbourne. The Department is also working closely with Services Australia to increase the number of appointments being provided to applicants in non-metropolitan areas. Further opportunities for the Department to draw upon the Services Australia network and to expand operations to support citizenship outcomes are under investigation. These initiatives are expected to help alleviate the client wait times in Victoria in due course.

Despite the impacts of COVID-19, from 1 July 2021 to 31 January 2022, there were 68,286 Australian citizenship tests administered and 79,479 people acquired Australian citizenship at ceremonies (38,135 people through online ceremonies and 41,344 people through in-person ceremonies).
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3675 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Skilled Migration Program
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 enclosing Petition EN3676 with 831 signatures, concerning Ms Evgeniya Stukalova and her daughter,
Ms Angelina Stukalova's request for Ministerial Intervention under section 351 of the Migration Act 1958 (the Act).

Section 351 of the Act provides me with the power to substitute a decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal with a more favourable decision, if I think it is in the public interest to do so. This is a non-compellable power and I am not obliged to consider a case or to intervene in a case.

A large number of requests for Ministerial Intervention are received and the Department of Home Affairs has been provided with guidelines on ministerial powers (s351, s417, s501J) regarding which cases should be referred for Ministerial consideration.

I can confirm Ms Stukalova and her daughter's request for Ministerial Intervention has been received by the Department. Requests for Ministerial Intervention are assessed on a case by case basis and processing timeframes vary due to individual circumstances.
Please be assured that the petition has been noted and the information provided will be taken into consideration when assessing their case.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3676 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke

Emerging Technologies
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 to the Minister for Science and Technology, the Hon Melissa Price MP, enclosing Petition EN3687 with 52 signatures, concerning emerging technologies such as biometrics and RFID. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Home Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

The Australian Government is committed to keeping Australians and their personal information safe. This includes the lawful, appropriate and ethical use of biometrics such as face images and fingerprints. The Government collects, uses and discloses biometrics as enabled under legislation such as the Privacy Act 1988 (the Privacy Act) and other legislation such as the Migration Act 1958 and the Passports Act 2005.

The Government does not engage in mass surveillance. The Government is not contemplating genetic testing of humans, or mandated implantation of microchips or radio-frequency identification devices, for the purpose of surveillance.

In October 2020, the Attorney-General's Department commenced a broad review of the Privacy Act (the Review). The Review is considering the adequacy of the Privacy Act in light of new and emerging technologies and whether the Privacy Act remains fit-for-purpose in the digital age.

In response to 200 submissions received on an Issues Paper, the Review released a Discussion Paper in October 2021, detailing proposals for reform of the Privacy Act. The Discussion Paper put forward a number of proposals that respond to the risks posed by new and emerging technologies. In particular, the Discussion Paper put forward options to expand the definition of personal information, strengthen protections for the collection, use and disclosure of personal information and enhance individual rights.

The Review has received 233 submissions in response to the Discussion Paper which will inform a final report to Government. This final report will propose reforms to the Privacy Act and will be made public following government consideration.
I have copied this letter to the Attorney-General, Senator the Hon Michaelia Cash, and the Minister for Science and Technology, the Hon Melissa Price MP.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3687 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 14 February 2022 concerning Petition EN3688 asking the House to request a Royal Commission be established to review the conduct of the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) and the Australian Health Practitioners Registration Authority (AHPRA) in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring that Australians have access to, and delivery of, safe and effective vaccines and treatment options for COVID-19 as soon as they are available, through our COVID-19 Vaccine and Treatment Strategy.

From the outset, I refute the call that there is a requirement to establish a Royal Commission into the conduct of the TGA, which is part of my Department, and reject the claim that the TGA has mishandled the evaluation of CQVID-9 vaccines and treatments. The role of the TGA, as the national medicines regulator, is to ensure that all therapeutic goods available on the Australian market are safe, of high quality and effective for their intended use, consistent with the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989.

I have full confidence that the TGA acts with integrity and within the requirements of this Act when evaluating the suitability of all therapeutic goods, including COVID-19 vaccines and treatments, for the Australian market. I also reject the petition's statement that the TGA has influence over AHPRA decision making. The TGA does not regulate the use of therapeutic goods, and how a therapeutic good is used or prescribed in medical practice is also outside the scope of the TGA's regulatory role.
I have provided information below in response to the issues raised in Petition EN3688.

I also strongly reject the petition's assertion that the Government and/ or the TGA have imposed artificial and unnecessary restrictions on any treatments for COVID-19. I presume this allegation is based on the restrictions on prescribing oral ivermectin.

Ivermectin has not received regulatory approval in Australia, or by other comparable international regulators, for the treatment or prevention of COVID-19. More evidence is required before ivermectin could be considered a safe and effective treatment option for routine use for this indication. This is the consensus view of international regulators and top- tier medical journals.

The restrictions on prescribing oral ivermectin were introduced by the TGA on 10 September 2021 on the advice of the Advisory Committee for Medicines Scheduling, an independent advisory committee comprised of medical and pharmaceutical experts from across Australia and representatives of the state and territory health departments. These changes were introduced following concerns about prescribing of oral ivermectin for the claimed prevention or treatment of COVID-19 in the context of insufficient evidence and potential for harm if an individual uses ivermectin in place of an approved treatment or vaccination.

GPs can continue to prescribe ivermectin for TOA-approved indications. Certain specialists including infectious disease physicians, dermatologists, gastroenterologists, and hepatologists may also prescribe ivermectin for other unapproved indications if they believe it is appropriate for a particular patient.

I also note that if a sponsor holds the appropriate evidence, they can make an application to the TGA at any time to register a new COVID-19 treatment or vaccine on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG). However, the Government cannot compel a sponsor to make an application for registration of a new medicine or a new indication for an approved medicine. In the absence of a formal application the TGA does not have the legal ability to grant approval, nor initiate an evaluation of the product.

I strongly refute the petition's statement that the COVID-19 vaccines being supplied in Australia were approved on the basis of scant evidence. The Standing Committee can be reassured that the TGA's review process of all vaccines, including COVID-19 vaccines, is rigorous. The TGA has found that the AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria), Biocelect (Novavax}and Janssen COVID-19 vaccines are safe and effective for use in adults over 18 years of age. Similarly, the Pfizer (Comirnaty) and Moderna (Spikevax) COVID-19 vaccines have been found to be safe and effective for use in adults, adolescents and children.

Due to the nature of the COVID-19 pandemic, all COVID-19 vaccines have been approved via the provisional approval pathway. Applications for provisional registration must include a comprehensive data package to support the medicine's safety, quality, and efficacy, as well as a source of product manufactured to pharmaceutical Good Manufacturing Practice requirements. Decisions on provisional registrations are also informed by expert advice from the Advisory Committee on Vaccines, an independent committee with expertise in scientific, medical and clinical fields including consumer representation.

The data submitted to support the quality, safety and efficacy of the COVID-19 vaccines showed a highly positive benefit-risk ratio. Waiting for data to establish the duration of protection would not have allowed these vaccines to have been available for mush of 2021. Continued approval is dependent upon the evidence of longer-term efficacy and safety from ongoing clinical trials and post-market assessment.

The TGA has published a range of documents relating to the provisional approval of each COVID-19 vaccine, which provide detailed information regarding the evaluation process and the data that were considered. These include the Australian Public Assessment Report (AusPAR), the Product Information and the Consumer Medicine Information.

The TGA has also published several documents in response to previous FOI requests at: www.tga.gov.au/foi-disclosure-log. These documents offer a useful summary and analysis of the data submitted to the TGA for the purposes of making a regulatory decision regarding the provisional approval of the COVID-19 vaccines.
The TGA closely monitors vaccine adverse events in Australia to identify trends and take regulatory action if needed. If a safety concern is identified it will be rapidly communicated to the public.

The TGA has robust procedures in place to detect and investigate signals for potential safety concerns with COVID-19 vaccines. If the TGA detects a safety concern, rapid action will be taken to address the safety issue and promptly provide information to the public. The TGA also undertakes an independent quality assessment of every batch of vaccine supplied in Australia. The TGA has robust procedures in place to detect and investigate signals for potential safety concerns with COVID-19 vaccines.

The TGA publishes information about its investigations of emerging safety signals, and the resulting regulatory actions, in the COVID-19 vaccine weekly safety report, which is available on its website at: www.tga.gov.au/periodic/covid-19-vaccine-weekly-safety-report.
Allegations of fraud in the Pfizer trials

Concerning allegations of fraud in the Pfizer vaccine clinical trials, Australians who have received the Pfizer vaccine should not be concerned about the issues raised in the British Medical Journal's (BMJ) article, available at:
.www.bmj.com/content/375/bmj.n2635.
The safety and efficacy of the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine demonstrated in clinical trials has been thoroughly substantiated by real-world use in many millions of people worldwide.

I can confirm that the TGA did contact Pfizer to further clarify the issues raised in the BMJ article. The allegations raised by a former staff member at a clinical trial site in the United States are not fraud but rather relate to poor clinical trial practices at a small trial site.

The Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine clinical trials were conducted in over 150 sites in multiple countries. The allegations raised in the BMJ article pertain to three sites (approximately 2% of the trial population) in the United States and there is no suggestion that other sites may be implicated. The overall results are therefore not expected to be impacted.
Thank you for the opportunity to respond to this petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Social Media
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence relating to Petition EN3718, which concerns the passage of the Social Media (Anti-Trolling) Bill 2022 (the Bill) and was referred to me as the responsible Minister. I acknowledge the concerns that signatories to the petition have raised about the Bill.
The Australian Government is committed to ensuring the safety of all Australians online, including in relation to defamatory material posted anonymously on social media.

Broadly speaking, the Bill seeks to achieve two outcomes. First, the Bill clarifies who is a publisher for the purposes of defamation law, following the High Court's recent decision in Fairfax Media Publications Pty Ltd v Voller (2021] HCA 27 (Voller). Second, the Bill creates new mechanisms for Australians to ascertain whether potentially defamatory material on social media was posted in Australia and, if so, to obtain the poster's relevant contact details in appropriate circumstances for the purposes of instituting defamation proceedings.

The impact of the Bill on privacy is reasonable, necessary and proportionate to achieve the Bill's objective, to support Australians to identify, and bring legal proceedings against, anonymous users who post defamatory material on social media. Further, the Bill includes a number of limitations and safeguards to minimise the impact on privacy as much as possible.

The Bill has been the subject of broad consultation and scrutiny, including through a House Select Committee inquiry into social media and online safety and the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee. Where appropriate, the Bill has been amended to address concerns that have been raised.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Michaelia Cash
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email dated 14 February 2022 to the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme and Minister for Government Services, Senator the Hon Linda Reynolds CSC, concerning petition EN3719 regarding the qualification criteria for the Disability Support Pension (DSP) and Carer Payment.
The petition was referred to me as the matters raised fall within my portfolio responsibilities.

DSP is designed to support people if they have a permanent physical, intellectual or psychiatric impairment which attracts at least 20 points under the Tables for the assessment of work-related impairment for Disability Support Pension (the Impairment Tables). When applying for DSP, the person must also be assessed as being unable to work for 15 or more hours per week, for at least the next two years, because of their impairment.

There is a rigorous claims process in place for DSP. Eligibility for DSP is based on functional impairment and ability to work, not on diagnosis or specific medical conditions alone. People claiming DSP are required to provide details about their medical condition(s) and ability to work as part of the claim process. They are required to provide medical evidence from their treating doctor, which includes information about their diagnosis, clinical features and symptoms, treatment and stability. Additional information from treating specialists and other health professionals may also be provided in support of the claim.

Most DSP claimants are referred for a Job Capacity Assessment. This assessment provides expert advice about the impairment rating and the impact of medical condition(s) on the person's capacity to work. An Assessor who is a health or allied health professional employed by Services Australia conducts the Job Capacity Assessment. All Assessors are appropriately qualified and trained.

In addition, claimants found to be medically eligible for DSP by an Assessor are required to undertake a Disability Medical Assessment, which is conducted by a Government contracted doctor. All Government contracted doctors are independent, qualified and trained to carry out these assessments.

Carer Payment is an income support payment paid to individuals who, because of the constant care they provide to a person with a disability or severe medical condition, are unable to support themselves through paid employment. 'Constant care' is the provision of personal care on a daily basis, for at least the equivalent of a normal working day.

The assessment process for Carer Payment considers the amount of help a person requires to undertake activities of daily living, such as communication, showering, toileting, grooming, dressing, feeding, mobility and a range of cognitive and behavioural activities. While this care can be active, supervisory or monitoring, only carers who are providing constant care will qualify for Carer Payment.
Thank you again for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Ms Ruston
Australian Citizenship Act
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 enclosing Petition EN3723 with 203 signatures, requesting that any recognised spouse of an Australian Defence Force (ADF) member, who is authorised to accompany that ADF member on an overseas posting should have the time spent accompanying the member at the posting locality treated as time spent in Australia for residency purposes.

The Australian Citizenship Act 2007 (the Act) sets out the legal requirements for Australian citizenship. Most applicants for Australian citizenship apply for citizenship through the conferral pathway. Applicants seeking to be approved under the conferral pathway are required to satisfy either the general residence requirement in section 22 of the Act, the special residence requirement (persons engaging in activities that are of benefit to Australia) in section 22A of the Act, the special residence requirement (persons engaged in particular kinds of work requiring regular travel outside Australia) in section 22B of the Act, or the defence service requirement in section 23 of the Act.

The majority of applicants for citizenship by conferral seek to meet the general residence requirement. Subsection 22(9) of the Act provides for Ministerial discretion to be applied to assist an applicant to meet the general residence requirement in certain circumstances, including where the person is the spouse, de facto partner or surviving spouse or de facto partner of an Australian citizen at the time the application is made.
This allows the Minister to treat a period spent overseas as if the person was present in Australia if:
the applicant was a spouse or de facto partner of the Australian citizen during the period; and
the applicant was not present in Australia during that period; and
the applicant was a permanent resident during that period; and
the Minister is satisfied that the person had a close and continuing association with Australia during that period.

Additionally, in recognition of the critical role of the ADF, the section 23 defence service requirement provides an alternate residence period for ADF lateral recruits, to support their undertaking to become Australian citizens. In 2021, the defence service requirement was extended to immediate family members of ADF personnel in the following specified circumstances:

the defence person was granted, on or after 1 July 2007, a Labour Agreement (Migrant) visa (class AU), a Labour Agreement (Residence) visa (class BV), an Employer Nomination (Permanent) visa (class EN); or a Regional Employer Nomination (Permanent) visa (class RN); and

the defence person was appointed, enlisted or transferred into any of the permanent forces or reserves of the Commonwealth of Australia and have served 90 days in the permanent forces; and has served a total of 90 paid service days in the navy, army or air force reserve; and was discharged from defence service as medically unfit for service as a result of that service; and
the applicant was a member of the family unit of the defence person when the defence person was granted the visa; and
the applicant holds a visa of that kind because they are a member of the family unit of the defence person.

Residency requirements for Australian citizenship applicants can be found on the Department of Home Affairs website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/citizenship/become-a-citizen/permanent-resident. The Department considers each case on its merits and would be happy to consider individual cases following from the advice provided above.
Where an individual's circumstances fall outside the legislative parameters under the Act, any amendments will require a bill to be tabled and considered by Parliament.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3723 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Religious Discrimination Bill
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 enclosing Petition EN3724 concerning the passage of the Religious Discrimination Bill.
Australia's anti-discrimination laws play an essential role in protecting the liberty of our citizens, each as individual human beings.
The Commonwealth has a Sex Discrimination Act, a Racial Discrimination Act, a Disability Discrimination Act and an Age Discrimination Act.
However, there is no standalone legislation to protect people of religion, or faith, against discrimination. Or indeed for those who choose not to have a faith or religion.
Recently, the Prime Minister introduced legislation to the Parliament to address this gap. The Religious Discrimination Bill included the recommendations of the Expe1i Panel on
Religious Freedom and followed an extensive public and stakeholder consultation process over a number of years.
The Bill, as introduced, ensured that:

discrimination on the ground of religious belief or activity would be unlawful in specified areas of public life (e.g. employment, education and the provision of goods and services), consistent with anti-discrimination laws;
religious schools would be free to hire teachers who share their faith; and

making a statement of belief (which would include sharing religious texts and prayer) would not be unduly restricted under state and territory law, provided it was done in good faith and did not cause harm to others.

It is also important to protect our children. That is why the Government also sought to amend existing provisions in the Sex Discrimination Act to ensure that children could not be expelled because of their sexual orientation, and proposed for the Australian Law Reform Commission to carefully review and consult on other exemptions in that act.
The government sought to pass these laws with the support of the Labor Party and crossbench.
Unfortunately, a number of amendments to this legislation, supported by the Labor Party in the House of Representatives, have compromised the core tenants of the legislation.

I want to assure you that protecting Australians from discrimination on the basis of their faith and beliefs remains a priority for our Government and we will continue to pursue these important reforms in the next parliament.
Please contact my office if you would like to discuss this important issue with me. I will be more than happy to do so.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Michaelia Cash
Migration Act
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 enclosing Petition EN3726 with two signatures, which seeks the formation of, and direction to an independent third party to investigate and itemise costs associated with the removal of unlawful non- citizens (UNC) from Australia to the United Kingdom; justification for the continual handcuffing of the UNC for the duration of a flight from Australia to the United Kingdom, and whether this constitutes any violation of human rights.
In accordance with the Migration Act 1958, the Australian Border Force (ABF) must, in certain circumstances, remove an UNC from Australia as soon as reasonably practicable.

To enable the removal of UNCs, the ABF utilise a suite of options, including unescorted removals via commercial flights when the detainee does not require security, medical or welfare escorts, escorted removals on commercial or charter flights using contracted security personnel and escorted removals on commercial flights using airline supplied security escorts.

The ABF is required to ensure that, when required by law or as a result of a risk assessment, security escorts are present during removal. The requirement for and role of security escorts in the aviation environment is governed by the Aviation Transport Security Act 2004, the Aviation Transport Security Regulations 2005 (ATSR) and the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) convention framework.
The following factors may determine a removee's need to be escorted:
the removee has a medical condition which requires support;
the removee has a mental health condition (including history of self-harm) which requires support;
the removee does not meet the definition of 'dangerous person' in the ATSR but is rated as a high risk and is assessed as requiring a security escort;
there are risks associated with the travel route or destination of removal; or
the removee fits the ATSR definition of 'dangerous person'.
Under the ATSR, a person who is in custody and determined to be a dangerous person must be escorted during removal from Australia. A dangerous person is defined as someone who:
is likely to attempt to commit an unlawful interference with aircraft; or
likely to attempt to escape; or

has been charged with an offence against a person or involving actual or threatened damage to property; and the offence is punishable by imprisonment for 5 years or more; and the charge is still to be resolved; or
the person has been convicted of an offence against a person or actual or threatened damage to property and the offence is punishable by imprisonment for 5 years or more.
Escort duties are performed by highly trained experts and come at a considerable additional cost to non-escorted removals.

A person who is removed from Australia, other than a person who came to Australia on a criminal justice visa, is liable to pay the Commonwealth the costs of his or her removal. Where a person has a debt to the Commonwealth, they will be unable to be granted another Australian visa unless appropriate arrangements have been made for the payment of the debt.

The use of restraints on an removee whilst in transit for the purposes of removal from Australia is at the discretion of the Department of Home Affairs' contracted Facilities and Detainee Services Provider, based on a thorough risk assessment and in line with departmental policies and procedures.

Before any escorted removal proceeds, the removee's risk assessment is provided to the airline provider as part of uplift approval. The airline provider considers the assessment and balances the potential risk of harm to the removee, other passengers, and crew, and damage to the aircraft, and determines if restraints can or must be utilised and under what circumstances.

Once the UNC and any escorts enter an aircraft, and the aircraft door is closed, the provisions of the ICAO convention framework apply, specifically the Convention on International Civil Aviation (the Chicago Convention) and the Convention on Offences and Certain Other Acts Committed On Board Aircraft (the Tokyo Convention). These conventions enable escorts to use force and to restrain UNCs being removed on commercial international flights and on charter aircraft if required.

The Tokyo Convention stipulates that if the pilot has reasonable grounds to believe that a person (including a removee) has committed or is about to commit, on board the aircraft, an offence against penal law or an act that may jeopardise the safety, good order or discipline on board the aircraft, they can impose on that person reasonable measures, including restraint, necessary to protect the safety of the aircraft or persons or property on board the aircraft. The Tokyo Convention also allows for any passenger (including an escort) to take reasonable preventive measures without the authorisation of the pilot if they have reasonable grounds to believe action is immediately necessary to protect the safety of the aircraft or persons or property on board the aircraft.

Departmental policy states that security escorts may only use restraints in exceptional circumstances, as a last resort, where the actions of the removee deem it necessary to achieve a safe removal, and for the minimum time required. Escorts must take all reasonable action to ensure that the removee does not suffer from physical harm whilst restrained.

Plastic flexi cuffs are generally used rather than handcuffs during removal activity as they are less restrictive and more comfortable for the removee. Security escorts must apply restraints appropriately and as comfortably as practicable and should not use them in a manner that is likely to cause injury, serious discomfort or potential danger to the removee. The use of restraints must be reasonable and proportionate to the perceived threat. The use of restraints during the removal process, to the extent that it is lawful, necessary, reasonable and proportionate, does not constitute a violation of a removee's human rights.

I am confident that Australia is committed to complying with its obligations under the ICAO convention framework provisions. Responsibility for the ICAO sits with the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Communications.

Any commentary on whether the costs associated with removal should be subject to an investigation cannot be made by National Removals or North and Detention Group. This part of the petition needs to be dealt with by another area—perhaps those responsible for the Financial Management Framework or commentary from Parliamentary Coordination regarding how to address such a petition.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3726 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
