Diabetes
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 concerning petition EN3757 requesting the reinstatement of Lantus® (insulin glargine) to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).
I note the petition signatories requesting the relisting of Lantus® on the PBS for type 1 diabetes. Lantus® was replaced by biosimilar products on the PBS.

The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC)—an independent and expert advisory body, comprising doctors, other health professionals and consumer representatives—makes recommendations to the Australian Government about PBS listings. Under legislation, the Government cannot list a new medicine (or amend an existing listing) on the PBS unless the PBAC makes a recommendation to do so.

Changes were made to PBS listings for insulin glargine from 1 July 2020, under the 'Biosimilars on the PBS' framework. The brands Lantus® and Lantus SoloStar® are subsequently no longer available on the PBS. Information about these changes can be found on the Biosimilars on the PBS web page at: www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/ Content/biosimilar-awareness-initiative.

Prior to biosimilar product changes, the Government is required to receive advice from the PBAC. A new biosimilar medicine is listed when the original reference medicine is already listed for the same population, and equivalence has been demonstrated. When it evaluates a medicine for PBS subsidy, the PBAC is required by legislation to take into account the effectiveness and cost by comparison to other alternative treatments.

The Biosimilar Awareness Initiative was intended to support awareness of, and confidence in, the use of biosimilar medicines for consumers and health care professionals. Prior to the delisting of Lantus® and Lantus SoloStar®, biosimilar equivalents were PBS listed from 1 January 2020.

A biosimilar medicine is highly similar to a 'reference biological medicine'. The reference biological medicine is the first brand to market. Biological medicines, including biosimilars, are used to treat serious diseases, such as diabetes.
Introduction of biosimilar medicines encourages competition in our Australian market.
This will lead to reduction in cost of medicines, resulting in savings to the health care system. These lower prices improve affordability and access to new treatments for seriously ill patients.

Biosimilar medicines are tested in Australia, and also checked for safety and health outcome equivalence by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), Australia's regulator of medicines and other therapeutic goods. Medicines are not generally made available on the PBS to treat conditions or patients that have not been approved by the TGA.
Biosimilar medicines have been used for over 10 years and are now used in over 60 countries. Lower costs and increased access to medicines has been demonstrated internationally.

All biological medicines currently listed on the PBS can be found on the PBS website at:
.www.pbs.gov.au/info/browse/biological-medicines-currently-listed-on-the-pbs#I.
Insulin products should automatically appear, but if not, they can be found under 'I', near the top of the page.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Water Safety
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 14 February 2022 concerning petition number EN3769 calling for a Nationwide Intensive School Swimming and Water Safety Program for primary and secondary school children.

The Australian Government has a longstanding history of supporting water safety initiatives and is committed to improving opportunities for community participation in sport and recreation in safe environments.

From 1 July 2021, the Government is providing an additional $39.1 million over three years to support national organisations through the Water and Snow Safety Program (Program). The Program supports activities and projects to protect lives and educate Australians, and international visitors, on the importance of safety in aquatic and alpine environments.

The funding is provided to key water safety organisations, such as Royal Life Saving Society Australia, Surf Life Saving Australia, AUSTSWIM and Laurie Lawrence Swimming Enterprises to deliver water safety outcomes. These organisations play a vital role in educating the Australian community about the risks of the water and deliver a range of targeted water safety initiatives, including swimming and water safety programs for children.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Sport, Senator Colbeck
Child Nutrition
Dear Chair
I refer to correspondence of 14 February 2022 regarding petition EN3792.

The Australian Government takes the wellbeing and safety of children and young people very seriously and works in partnership with jurisdictions to support safe and supportive learning environments that promote wellbeing, resilience and learning outcomes for children and young people. The Australian Government also plays a leadership role in both schools and early childhood education.

The Education and Care Services National Law Act (National Law) and National Regulations sets a national standard for children's education and care., The National Quality Framework (NQF) provides a national approach to regulation, assessment and quality improvement for early childhood education and care and outside school hours care services across Australia.
More information on the NQF is available at www.acecqa.gov.au/nqf/about and more information on National Law is available at www.acecqa.gov.au/nqf/national-law- regulations.

The aim of Quality Area 2 under the National Quality Standard is to safeguard and promote children's health and safety, minimise risks and protect children from harm, injury and infection: Acknowledging that good nutrition is essential to healthy living and enables children to be active participants in play and leisure, education and care services must ensure healthy eating and physical activity are promoted and appropriate for each child.

Education and care services are encouraged to provide food that is consistent with the Australian Government guidelines Get Up & Grow: Healthy Eating and Physical Activity for Early Childhood (www.health.gov.au/resources/collections/get-up-grow-resource-collection), and the Australian Dietary Guidelines (www.eatforhealth,gov.au/guidelines). The provision of food should also be in line with advice provided by families about their child's dietary requirements, and any other requirements families have regarding their child's nutrition.

In schools education, while the Australian Government plays a leadership role in setting and advocating for national priorities for school education, and provides significant funding for schools and school systems, the management and delivery of school education is the responsibility of state and territory education authorities. This includes ensuring that appropriate measures such as school nursing programs are in place to support the health and wellbeing needs of school communities. In some instances, decisions about issues such as healthy eating may occur at the school level.
I have copied this letter to the Hon Mark Butler MP, Minister for Health and Aged Care. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Early Childhood Education and Minister for Youth, Dr Aly
COVID-19: Testing
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence regarding Petition number EN3796, which requests the House enact a bill to subsidise and make rapid antigen tests (RATs), both oral and nasal, free to everyone across Australia.

The Australian Government continues to make RATs available to people in high-risk priority groups to manage health impacts and protect vulnerable Australians, particularly those at risk of severe disease. This includes people in Residential Aged Care Facilities (RACFs), Aboriginal and Community Controlled Health Services and GP-led Respiratory Clinics particularly in remote and rural communities where there is limited access to testing.

RATs continue to be distributed to RACFs to prevent outbreaks through screening of workers, and to limit outbreaks when they occur by testing residents and workers. Polymerase chain reaction tests (PCR) and RATs remain free through Government-run testing clinics, for people who are suspected to have COVID-19.

Whilst there was limited supply of RATs both internationally and in Australia in early 2022, these supply challenges have now been resolved, resulting in pharmacies, supermarkets and other retail settings now having sufficient stock to meet consumer demand within Australia.

As you may be aware, COVID-19 tests (including PCR and RATs) are tax deductible for Australians who are required to conduct testing for work-related purposes. This change took effect from the beginning of the 2021-22 tax year and will be in place permanently.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Lefevre Peninsula
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 14 February 2022 regarding a petition seeking the Australian Rail Track Corporation (ARTC) to develop a Community Safety and Liveability Plan for communities around the Lefevre Peninsula, in South Australia (EN3797). I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring all Australians can safely enjoy the benefits of rural living, particularly communities who reside close to industrial land and freight rail corridors. I agree that contamination on public or private land must be appropriately managed to ensure the safety of nearby communities. Maintaining the safety and habitability of communities along the Lefevre Peninsula, including public land adjacent to the Outer Harbour freight rail corridor, is the responsibility of the City of Port Adelaide Enfield local government area. This responsibility includes any future development of a Community, Safety and Liveability Plan.

The ARTC is responsible for the Outer Harbour freight corridor that runs along the Lefevre Peninsula and terminates at Pelican Point Road. The passenger rail line is managed by the South Australian Government through Adelaide Metro. Rail owners and operators, including the ARTC, must undertake periodic maintenance activities across the rail network to ensure continued safe track operation. This work is essential to maintain the rail network and complementary trackside infrastructure. Control measures include regular track inspections, annual vegetation control, pest control programs and safety reviews. Maintenance works are undertaken where appropriate.

As an Australian Government Business Enterprise, the ARTC was created with specific obligations for maintaining the rail corridor. These obligations must be undertaken in accordance with the relevant state or territory lease arrangement. These arrangements also stipulate the ARTC is responsible for monitoring and maintaining the existing perimeter fences.

The ARTC is not required to develop a Community, Safety and Liveability Plan or undertake maintenance or upgrades that are not part of these lease agreements. Managing vegetation can be challenging due to the complexities of protected species protection, land holder concerns and relevant environmental legislation. In response to this growing challenge, the ARTC continues to increase their annual vegetation management spending. The ARTC's current year to date estimates indicate vegetation management spending has n:iore than doubled in comparison to the previous year.

In accordance with the ARTC's Annual Vegetation Management Plan, scheduled track inspections are undertaken. A community feedback line, managed by the ARTC, enables train controllers or the general public to report vegetation management issues. Specialist contractors are procured to deliver the required remedial works. Since 2013, the ARTC has responded and resolved eleven community resident enquiries regarding overgrown vegetation, illegal dumping, maintenance of fencing and train speed/noise along the Lefevre Peninsula.

In South Australia, the ARTC is required to comply with the Environment Protection Act 1993 (SA) and the South Australian Environmental Protection Agency (SA EPA) requirements. The ARTC operations are licensed by the SA EPA under licence 10555. There are no operational noise requirements outlined within the licence.

In 2012, the ARTC undertook noise monitoring on the Lefevre Peninsula and found noise levels were consistent with normal operational rail noise. The number and type of trains has not changed substantially since this date.

The ARTC invite the parties to the petition to contact Lincoln Carter through the ARTC Enviroline via: enviroline@artc.com.au or 1300 550 402, to arrange a meeting to discuss their concerns. The ARTC representatives from the ARTC Lefevre Peninsula/South Australia Operations team, Adrian Oorloff, Corridor Manager, and Paul Thalassinos, Area Manager, are available from the week commencing 25 April 2022.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, Mr Joyce

The Civil Aviation Safety Authority has advised me that no aviation safety incidents related to the COVID-19 pandemic or COVID-19 vaccinations have been reported to them, and they are not aware of any adverse events or impacts on the medical status for any aviation staff in Australia due to the COVID-19 vaccine.

from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, Mr Joyce
Asylum Seekers
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 enclosing Petition EN3807 with 31 signatures, concerning the release of immigration detainees to assist with labour shortages resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic. Your petition has been referred to me as the Minister for Home Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio of responsibilities.

To respond to labour shortages brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic, the Australian Government implemented a range of temporary measures to allow migrants to lawfully extend their stay and work in Australia.

The Government is committed to upholding the integrity of the migration program and protecting Australia from non-citizens who pose a risk to the safety and good order of the community. Non-citizens visiting or living in Australia are expected to abide by their visa conditions and the law. Immigration detention is part of strong border control. Non-compliance and visa integrity issues are managed in the community where possible and immigration detention is a measure of last resort. Therefore, the Government does not support granting of visas to immigration detainees en masse to fulfill labour shortages.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3807 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition number EN3812 on COVID-19 vaccination. I regret the delay in responding.

Vaccination is a safe and effective means of preventing the spread and development of diseases such as COVID-19 in the community. The Australian Government encourages everyone to be vaccinated as soon as they are eligible.

When enough people in the community are immunised, it becomes more difficult for the virus to spread. This helps to protect people who are at greater risk of getting the disease, including unvaccinated members of the community.

Evidence from recent scientific research demonstrates that vaccination helps to protect against severe illness, hospitalisation and death from SARS-CoV-2 infection. The 'COVID-19 vaccine surveillance report-week 11' at:
.www.assets.publishing.service.gov.uk provides current research on ongoing monitoring of vaccine effectiveness and population impact in the United Kingdom. 'Effectiveness of mRNA vaccination in preventing COVID-19-associated invasive mechanical ventilation and death—United States, March 2021-January 2022' in the Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report at: www.cdc.gov provides updated information on COVID-19 messenger ribonucleic acid vaccine protection against hospitalisation in adults.

People who are unvaccinated are at greater risk of severe illness from COVID-19. Vaccination is especially important when it comes to protecting Australians who are at greater risk of severe illness, such as people over 70 years old, with pre-existing health conditions and weakened immune systems.

The emergence of new variants and the ability of variants to evade immunity from past infection or vaccination contributes to breakthrough infections. Vaccination has helped protect people with breakthrough infections from serious illness, hospitalisation and death.

The Petitions Committee can be assured that the Government, along with the states and territories, is taking an evidence-based approach to COVID-19 and is committed to protecting the health of Australians.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt

subdebateinfo.title: National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Cultural Precinct

p.span: National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Cultural Precinct
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 14 February 2022 notifying me of petition EN3818 to the House of Representatives, which seeks a reversal of the Australian Government's decision to establish the Ngurra Cultural Precinct.
The Australian Government is committed to ensuring Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultures are recognised and celebrated by all Australians.
Australia is home to the oldest continuing living cultures in the world. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples have existed and cared for Country for more than 65,000 years.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples come from many diverse nations across the Australian continent, each with their own distinct customs, language and lore.

Today, Australia's national cultural institutions all play a part in telling our national story, which has millennia of Indigenous heritage at its foundation. The establishment of the Ngurra Cultural Precinct will be the realisation of a long-held desire to have a home for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultures at the heart of our nation. All Australians and visitors to our nation will be able to gain a deeper appreciation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples' diversity and cultures, and the richness this offers our country.

The Precinct will include a National Resting Place. For more than 200 years the remains of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples were removed from Country and placed in museums, universities, and private collections in Australia and overseas. The Government supports repatriation of ancestral remains to their communities of origin. The National Resting Place will address the lack of a holistic facility to perform the functions of housing and caring for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander ancestral remains repatriated to Australia from overseas with limited or unknown provenance.

The Precinct will also include a learning and knowledge centre and a new home for the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies (AIATSIS). AIATSIS is Australia's only national institution focused exclusively on the diverse history, cultures and heritage of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australia. It maintains a collection of more than one million items, which will now be more accessible to the public.

Importantly, the Ngurra Cultural Precinct will provide a new perspective and opportunities for engagement with our shared history. I am confident it will become a national landmark, standing proudly for us all to celebrate, educate, reflect and commemorate.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Indigenous Australians, Mr Wyatt
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence to the former Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Greg Hunt, regarding petition EN3822 requesting that the House of Representatives legislate to stop the entry of any non-citizen who has not been fully vaccinated against COVID-19, and to not allow any exceptions from this proposed requirement.

From 6 July 2022, the majority of COVID-19-related Australian border restrictions were removed. These restrictions have served Australia well and were based on expert medical advice and reviewed ·regularly. They helped Australia to avoid much of the human and economic harm experienced around the world, but as we move to the next phase of the pandemic, they have now served their purpose.

From 6 July 2022, people have been able to travel to and from Australia without being required to declare their COVID-19 vaccination status. Wearing masks remains a current requirement on international flights to Australia. We encourage all travellers to be vaccinated for their own protection.

All incoming travellers will need to comply with relevant state and territory testing requirements, where applicable. It is the responsibility of incoming travellers to check testing requirements for the state or territory they are visiting.
The Australian Government will continue to be guided by medical advice, monitor global developments and adjust international border controls, where required.

Everyone has an important role to play in minimising the risk of COVID-19 and we encourage all visitors to Australia to practice COVID safe behaviours. Travellers are still encouraged to wear a mask in indoor settings, particularly where physical distancing is not possible.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Invictus Games
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence regarding Petition EN3865 to the former Minister for Sport, Senator the Hon Richard Colbeck. As the outcome of the election is now known, I will respond as the current Minister for Sport regarding the eligibility criteria for Australian Sports Medal recipients. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Sports Medal was created to recognise the efforts of Australians who made our country a nation of sporting excellence. The Australian Sports Medal was awarded during the year 2000, the year in which Sydney hosted the Olympic and Paralympic Games. It was awarded to current and former competitors, coaches, sports scientists, office holders, and individuals who maintained sporting facilities and services.

On 4 December 2020, amendments were made to the regulations for the Australian Sports Medal to mean the medal will be able to be awarded for Australian sporting participation in multi-sports events, including the Invictus Games from 2018. I understand and appreciate it is the wish of the 108 signatories to Petition EN3865, that participants, carers, and support staff of the 2014, 2016, and 2017 Australian lnvictus Games Teams also be eligible to receive this award.

Details regarding the eligibility criteria, administration and application process, as well as any future amendments to the Australian Sports Medal will be published at www.pmc.gov.au/government/its-honour/australian-sports-medal.

The achievements of the Australian lnvictus teams have inspired many since the event's inception in London 2014, and the Australian lnvictus team members are to be commended for the sacrifices they have made in the pursuit of excellence and for their service to our country.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Sport, Ms Wells
National Diabetes Services Scheme
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 31 March 2022 to the former Minister for Health and Aged Care regarding petition EN3885, requesting the expansion of free access to glucose monitoring technology through the National Diabetes Services Scheme (scheme) to include all adults living with cystic fibrosis related diabetes.
From 1 July 2022, the Australian Government will be significantly expanding access to subsidised Continuous Glucose Monitoring (CGM) products, in this instance to adults with type 1 diabetes.

Following implementation of this expansion, the government will continue to monitor the operation of the scheme. This will inform government consideration of any further expansion of the scheme to adults with other forms of diabetes.
Information about the CGM Initiative and the expanded eligibility criteria, are available on the scheme website at www.ndss.com.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Commonwealth Integrity Commission
Dear Chair

I refer to correspondence of 31 March 2022 from Mr Ken O'Dowd MP, in his then capacity as Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, regarding Petition EN3893. The petition expresses concern about Australia's 2020 ranking on Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index and calls for the establishment of a federal anti-corruption body. I welcome the opportunity to provide a response to this petition for consideration by the Committee in the 4 7th Parliament.
The Australian Government is committed to ensuring integrity and accountability in the federal government by legislating a powerful, transparent and independent National
Anti-Corruption Commission. The Government intends to legislate by the end of 2022 to enable the Commission to become operational in 2023.

The Government has publicly released seven design principles, based on the advice of experts, that will ensure the Commission operates effectively. The Commission will be empowered to investigate serious or systemic corruption involving Commonwealth ministers, public servants, statutory officer holders, government agencies and contractors, parliamentarians, and staff of politicians, and may investigate both criminal and non- criminal corrupt conduct. It will be able to commence inquiries on its own initiative or in response to referrals from any person and will have the power to hold public hearings where it is in the public interest to do so.
The legislation will implement these design principles and also draw on lessons from the operation of state and territory anti-corruption commissions.

Establishing a national agency with a dedicated focus on detecting and investigating serious or systemic corruption will strengthen Australia's integrity framework. The Commission will form a central pillar of Australia's integrity framework and will help to improve perceptions of the integrity of our public institutions.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mark Dreyfus
Housing Affordability
Dear Secretary
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN3904 on affordable housing rental prices. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Albanese Government has made building more social housing, upgrading existing housing and making home ownership achievable for more Australians a particular policy priority. We want every Australian to know the security of having a roof over their head.

As you may be aware, the Government has announced that it will establish a $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund. This will support the construction of 30,000 new social and affordable housing properties in its first five years. Each year investment returns from the Fund will be transferred to the Government's National Housing Finance and Investment Corporation (NHFIC) to pay for social and affordable housing projects. Investment returns will also fund acute housing needs (such as for remote Indigenous communities, those impacted by domestic violence and those facing homelessness) on an ongoing basis.

The Government will also establish a National Supply and Affordability Council to ensure the Commonwealth plays a greater leadership role in increasing housing supply and improving housing affordability. The Council will have a key role in setting targets, making available housing data and research, and providing advice on planning, supply and affordability. The Council will help develop and implement the new National Housing and Homelessness Plan. This will set out the key short, medium and long-term reforms needed to make it easier for Australians to buy a home, easier to rent, and put a roof over the heads of more homeless Australians.

In 2022-23 the Australian Government expects to spend around $7.2 billion to improve housing and homelessness outcomes. This includes an expected $5 billion in Commonwealth Rent Assistance to help eligible Australians on welfare payments pay their rent and around $1.6 billion a year through the National Housing and Homelessness Agreement (NHHA) to states. Commonwealth Rent Assistance has a considerable impact on reducing rental stress. In 2020, the proportion of Commonwealth Rent Assistance recipients facing rental stress was 29 per cent, compared to 55 per cent if this cohort were not receiving Commonwealth Rent Assistance.

Finally, the Government's National Housing Finance and Investment Corporation is supporting the provision of more social and affordable housing through its administration of the Affordable Housing Bond Aggregator (AHBA) and the National Housing Infrastructure Facility (NHIF). The AHBA provides cheaper, long-term finance for community housing providers (CHPs), while the NHIF provides finance for critical infrastructure underpinning housing supply, particularly affordable housing. Since its commencement in 2018, the NHFIC Board has approved over $2.9 billion of loans to CHPs under the AHBA to date, supporting over 15,000 new and existing homes; and over $427 million in NHIF transactions supporting the delivery of more than 6,900 new social, affordable and market dwellings.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing, Ms Collins
Private Health Insurance
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 31 March 2022 to the former Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Greg Hunt, concerning petition number EN3906. This matter has been referred to me as the Minister for Health and Aged Care.
The Australian Government has a range of processes in place to ensure new migrants are made aware of their entitlements and responsibilities as new Australian citizens.

When new migrants to Australia apply for permanent residency and enrol in Medicare, whether on an Interim or Permanent basis, they are informed about Lifetime Health Cover (LHC). Additionally, when an individual receives their Medicare card, they are advised about the potential consequences of not having private health insurance, including LHC. The responsible Government agency, Services Australia, provides information about Medicare arrangements in a range of languages, including online, via phone, or in-person interpreter and translation services.

The Government also undertakes an annual LHC mailout. This correspondence is directed to all Australian residents who do not hold domestic private health hospital cover and may be approaching the date at which LHC will apply to them. This mailout provides information as to why a recipient is receiving the letter, what type of hospital cover they need to purchase, and by when they need to purchase domestic private health insurance hospital cover to avoid an LHC loading.
For migrants who move to Australia after their 30th birthday, this reminder letter is provided as they approach the 12-month anniversary of their initial enrolment in Medicare.

There is no discretion within the. Private Health Insurance Act (2007) which allows for an exemption to LHC loading to be granted under any circumstances. However, given the importance of LHC in encouraging people to take out and maintain private health hospital cover, the 2020-21 Budget included funding for an independent actuarial study of its effectiveness. This study will inform any future adjustments to how LHC is applied.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Illicit Drugs
Dear Chair

I refer to correspondence from the Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions regarding petition EN3916, which seeks to decriminalise possession of cannabis and allow two cannabis plants to be grown at one time.

In relation to the matters presented in this petition, I would like to assure you that the Australian Government is committed to preventing and minimising the harms associated with the use of illicit drugs, including cannabis, on individuals, families, and communities. This is being achieved through the implementation of a broad range of evidence-based demand, supply and harm reduction strategies that are aligned to Australia's National Drug Strategy (Strategy) to deliver a balanced approach between health and law enforcement.

The Strategy identifies cannabis as a priority substance for action and outlines a range of evidence-based approaches to minimise harms associated with its use. The potential harms from cannabis use depend on the age of the person, pattern of use and other risky behaviours and health concerns.

While many Australians may view cannabis as harmless, approximately 20% of Australia's drug and alcohol treatment services are being provided to people identifying cannabis as their principal drug of concern. It is also important to note that the use of any illicit drug in any quantity is a high-risk activity that has the potential to cause significant health, social and economic harms

State and territory governments largely have responsibility for matters relating to the legalisation and/or decriminalisation of illicit drugs in their respective jurisdiction. As such, the petitioner may like to also raise this matter with their relevant state or territory government. Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Chair

I refer to correspondence of 31 March 2022 to the former Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Greg Hunt, regarding petition EN3921 requesting that the House of Representatives allow inbound arrivals for all vaccinated persons without quarantine. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The human biosecurity emergency period under the Biosecurity Act 2015, was declared on 18 March 2020 in response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lapsed on 17 April 2022 as the Australia transitioned to living with the virus. Since 18 April 2022 international travellers entering Australia have not been required to present a negative pre-departure test at check-in to their flights.

On 3 July 2022, I announced additional changes to the requirements of travellers at Australia's international borders at www.health.gov.au/ministers/the-hon-mark-butler-mp/media/changes-to-requirements-for-international-arrivals.

From 6 July 2022, travellers have able to travel to and from Australia without being required to declare their COVID-19 vaccination status. Wearing masks remains a current requirement on international flights to Australia.

Airlines and cruise lines may also have specific vaccination, testing or mask-wearing requirements. All passengers are strongly encouraged to familiarise themselves with these requirements by contacting their airline or cruise ship operator directly.
Travellers are reminded that it is their responsibility to ensure they meet the requirements of the airline they are travelling with and any countries they transit through.

Further information regarding international travel and COVID-19 is available on the Department of Health and Aged Care at www.health.gov.au/health-alerts/covid-19/international-travel and Department of Home Affairs at
.www.homeaffairs.gov.au/covid19 websites.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition number EN3926, requesting that there be no mandate or law or compulsory requirement for vaccination of any Australian person.
I apologise for the delay in responding.

Immunisation is a safe and effective health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, morbidity, or mortality. Immunisation is not compulsory in Australia, and people maintain the right to choose whether to vaccinate themselves and their family.

Vaccines available in Australia have been rigorously tested, evaluated and approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration to ensure they meet stringent safety and efficacy guidelines. Vaccines continue to be tested after their introduction via additional clinical trials, surveillance and monitoring of vaccine adverse events.

Vaccines, like any other medicines can have side effects, however all vaccines used within Australia provide benefits which greatly outweigh their risks. Various organisations, including the Australian Academy of Science, have documented this evidence and found that vaccinating against diseases is safer and more effective than being infected with those diseases.

The Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI) is constantly reviewing information included in the Australian Immunisation Handbook (Handbook), which provides clinical advice for health professionals on the safest and most effective use of vaccines in their practice. You can find further information concerning vaccine safety on the Department of Health website at www.health.gov.au/health-topics/immunisation/about-immunisation/are- vaccines-safe.

States and territories have primary responsibility for public-health measures in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice. Some states and territories have public-health orders which require vaccination for people in high-risk workplaces and sectors. Further information about these public-health orders can be found on state or territory government websites.

Some employers have mandated vaccinations for their employees. For individual businesses not covered by a public-health order, whether to require vaccinations for employees needs careful consideration, taking into account the relevant employment, discrimination, work health and safety, and privacy laws, and the circumstances of the particular workplace. The employers and employees are encouraged to work together on workplace vaccination arrangements.

Some individuals are unable to receive vaccines due to having a severe allergy or illness. Where vaccination has been made mandatory, there are exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical reasons.

Medical contraindications to vaccination are rare. The medical basis for a medical contraindication is clinical guidance from ATAGI and the Handbook. Immunisation medical contraindications can be granted for one or more vaccines on a permanent or temporary basis.
Individuals with a medical contraindication to vaccines can ask their GP, or other eligible health professional, to report a medical contraindication to the Australian Immunisation Register.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
National Disability Insurance Scheme
Dear Mr O'Dowd

I refer to your email of 31 March 2022 concerning Petition EN3931 to the House of Representatives to allow National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) funding to be released to families to help pay for costs associated with a sudden death of a participant.

The death of a loved one is always difficult and especially so when the death is unexpected or that of a child. I give my condolences to all those who have experienced this grief, particularly to the family of Caleb who created this petition.

As you may be aware, the NDIS was designed to support Australians with permanent and significant disability to access and receive funding to meet the cost of their specialist disability support needs. Under the National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013, a person ceases to be an NDIS participant when they die and at this point their plan ends.

The Government recognises the death of a family member can cause emotional distress and financial hardship. To this end, the National Disability Insurance Agency (NDIA) has a dedicated Bereavement Team to provide support to families and carers. The Bereavement Team is the single point of contact after the NDIA is notified of a participant's death. The Bereavement Team offers assistance to the families and carers of deceased participants to finalise all aspects of the plan and/or provide guidance for them to finalise the plan.
The NDIA can help with:
notifying service providers to cease providing supports and requesting the finalisation of all outstanding invoices for services delivered;
where required, liaising with Supported Independent Living or Specialist Disability Accommodation providers for the removal of personal items and/or modifications;
finalising service bookings after providers have processed all outstanding claims; and
discussing options relating to any assistive technology or home modifications purchased through the participant's NDIS plan.

The NDIS does not fund funeral expenses as it is designed to complement, and not replace, existing mainstream, community and family supports. Mainstream supports are those available to everyone in each state or territory, or across Australia, whether or not they have a disability.
There are various mainstream bereavement supports available to people in Australia, including those offered by Australian governments.

When a care receiver dies, recipients of Carer Payment will continue to receive their payment for 14 weeks. This continuation of Carer Payment recognises the carer will require some time to adjust their lifestyle from that of a caring role and may need to seek employment or another form of income support.

In addition to the 14-week payment continuation, a lump sum Bereavement Payment may also be payable for both Carer Payment and Carer Allowance. The purpose of bereavement payments is to assist with settling the care receiver's financial affairs.

It is through these arrangements the Government assists families to pay for the costs associated with the unexpected loss of a loved one, including people who were receiving support through the NDIS at the time of their death.
I trust this information clarifies the matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, Senator Reynolds
Centrelink
Dear Chair

Thank you for the email from the Committee dated 31 March 2022 concerning petition EN3938, which requests an increase to the rate of income support payments in response to rising cost of living pressures. The email was referred to the former Minister for Families and Social Services and Minister for Women's Safety, Senator the Hon Anne Ruston, as this matter fell within her former portfolio responsibilities. This matter now falls within my portfolio responsibilities as the Minister for Social Services.

The Prime Minister has stated that the Government does not have a plan to increase the rate of income support payments in the Government's first Budget, noting the importance of acting in a fiscally responsible manner. He further stated that the Government would consider the rates of payments in future Budgets and do what it can to help those in need.

The Government recognises that living on income support payments is challenging, and that it is important that the rate of payments keep up with the cost of living. To address the effects of inflation on the cost of living for those on a payment, income support payments are increased each year in March and September in line with the Consumer Price Index.

When people on an income support payment have additional expenses, supplementary payments are available to support them. These payments include Rent Assistance for recipients in the rental market and Family Tax Benefit to assist with the cost of raising children. Other supplementary benefits include Carer Allowance, Pharmaceutical Allowance, Mobility Allowance, Remote Area Allowance, Telephone Allowance and access to a concession card.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth

subdebateinfo.title: Women's Sanitary Products in Public Hospitals

p.span: Women's Sanitary Products in Public Hospitals
Dear Chair

I refer to correspondence of 30 March 2022 from the former Minister for Health regarding petition EN3939 which requests the Australian Government mandate the provision of free period products and maternity pads in public hospitals.

The importance of patients' dignity and privacy being maintained during health care provision has been recognised by the Australian Commission on Safety and Quality in Health Care (Commission). The Commission's Australian Charter of Healthcare Rights describes the key rights patients and health consumers can expect when receiving health care, including a patient's right to be treated with dignity and respect.

Through the National Health Reform Agreement (NHRA), the government provides significant funding to assist states and territories with the costs of delivering public hospital services. The NHRA, however, recognises that state and territory governments are the system managers of their public hospital systems, responsible for the day-to-day administration of their public hospitals.

Decisions regarding the provision of free period products and maternity pads in public hospitals therefore rest with the state or territory governments and individual hospitals involved. The Australian Government does not have the power to mandate that states and territories provide these products free of charge to patients. As such, the petitioners may wish to contact their respective state or territory Health Ministers, regarding the issues raised in this petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Medicare
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 31 March 2022 concerning petition EN3941 seeking public funding through the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) for patients to have areola tattooing after undergoing breast augmentation surgery as a result of breast cancer.

The Australian Government supports Australians to access high-quality health care by providing both free and subsidised health care services. This includes providing Medicare benefits (rebates) for privately rendered services listed on the MBS, and funding to state and territory governments for free hospital services for public patients in public hospitals.
The MBS is a list of the medical services for which the Government provides a rebate, to provide patients with financial assistance towards the costs of the medical services.
Under the MBS, an areola tattoo is classified as cosmetic surgery. The MBS explicitly states that non-therapeutic cosmetic surgery services do not attract Medicare benefits.

There are surgical options for nipple and/or areola reconstruction and intradermal colouration provided in hospital, for which an MBS rebate is available under MBS items 45545 and 45546. Further information about these options can be found online at www.mbsonline.gov.au by searching these item numbers.

The Department of Health relies on the sound clinical judgement of medical practitioners to determine whether a patient meets the eligibility criteria for accessing services on the MBS. For a new medical service to be publicly funded through the MBS, it must first be assessed by the Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC). The MSAC is an independent expert committee comprising individuals with expertise in clinical medicine, health economics and consumer health.

The MSAC appraises new medical services and provides advice to Government on whether they should be publicly funded based on an assessment of its comparative safety, clinical effectiveness and cost effectiveness, using the best available evidence. These processes ensure Australians have access to medical services and medicines that have been shown to be safe and clinically effective, as well as representing value for money for both patients and taxpayers.

Anyone is able to submit an application to MSAC, however due to the level of evidence that would be required, a medical professional group is generally best placed to provide the necessary research and trial data. More information about the MSAC process is available at: www.msac.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Diabetes
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 31 March 2022 to the former Minister for Health and Aged Care regarding petition EN3942, requesting that the Australian Government fully subsidise continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) technology for all people living with type 1 diabetes.
I am pleased to advise that from 1 July 2022, all Australians with type 1 diabetes will have access to subsidised CGM products through the National Diabetes Services Scheme.

The Department of Health is working closely with key stakeholders to support this change. Details of implementation arrangements, including advice on how to apply for access to the expanded CGM Initiative, will be provided before 1 July 2022 on the National Diabetes Services Scheme website at www.ndss.com.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 31 March 2022 concerning petition number EN3948 requesting extending access to cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) modulators such as Trikafta® (elexacaftor/tezacaftor/ivacaftor and ivacaftor), on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) for the treatment of cystic fibrosis associated with a broader range of mutations.

Trikafta® was recently listed on the PBS from 1 April 2022. This listing will provide subsidised access for patients with cystic fibrosis aged 12 years and older, who have at least one F508del mutation in the CFTR gene.

The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC)—an independent expert body comprising doctors, other health professional and consumer representatives—makes recommendations to the Australian Government about PBS listings. Under legislation, the Government cannot list a new medicine on the PBS unless the PBAC makes a recommendation in favour of its listing.

The pharmaceutical company responsible for Trikafta®, and the other CFTR modulators Symdeko® (tezacaftor/ivacaftor and ivacaftor), Orkambi® (lumacaftor/ivacaftor) and Kalydeco® (ivacaftor), Vertex Pharmaceuticals (Australia) Pty Ltd, has not made an application to the PBAC for a broader listing of these medicines.
Further, the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), Australia's regulator of medicines and other therapeutic goods, has not approved Trikafta® for broader clinical use in Australia.
Medicines typically are not listed on the PBS for clinical uses that have not been approved by the TGA.

Consideration of a medicine for TGA registration and PBS listing is generally initiated by the sponsor making applications to the TGA and PBAC, respectively. Pharmaceutical companies have access to the scientific· data and other information necessary to inform the PBAC's consideration.
The PBAC would welcome further applications related to the use of Trikafta® or other CFTR modulators at any time.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Australian Research Council
Dear Chair
I refer to correspondence of 31 March 2022 regarding Petition Number EN3949.
I note the concerns expressed by petitioners regarding the vetoing of 6 ARC Discovery Project grants in late 2021 by the Hon Stuart Robert MP, former Acting Minister for Education and Youth.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring the integrity and transparency of the Australian Research Council's grant assessment processes. It is currently considering the recommendations of the Senate Education and Employment Legislation Committee's Inquiry into the Australian Research Council Amendment (Ensuring Research Independence) Bill contained in its Report dated 21 March 2022.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Clare
Taxation
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to petition EN2640 on removing late tax return lodgement penalties for the year 2019/2020, originally sent on 22 June 2021 to the then Treasurer, the Hon Josh Frydenberg MP. Following the election this correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I appreciate the concerns raised in the petition about the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on Australians as well as the financial impact of late lodgement penalties. Penalties for failure to lodge on time are important in encouraging taxpayers to lodge their tax returns on time. 1hese incentives help to ensure that there is no delay or uncertainty in revenue collections, as this revenue helps to deliver public services, social safety nets and reliable infrastructure for all Australians. Incentives to lodge on time would be weakened if the Government retrospectively repealed late lodgement penalties.

I understand though that sometimes people don't meet their lodgment obligations on time, even with the best intentions. Generally, the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) does not apply penalties in isolated cases of late lodgement, and in the first instance will provide a warning. If a penalty notice is received for failing to lodge on time, a taxpayer can ask for it to be remitted if there are extenuating circumstances. The ATO will consider remitting interest and penalties incurred after 23 January 2020 for taxpayers that have been adversely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic.
If interest and penalties were incurred before 23 January 2020, taxpayers should still contact the ATO as they can consider their circumstances.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
Internet Content
Social Media
Dear Committee Secretary
I write with regard to two petitions, EN2662 and EN3731, which fall within my Portfolio responsibilities.

On 21 June 2021, the former Committee Chair, Mr Ken O'Dowd MP, wrote to my predecessor, the then Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, the Hon Paul Fletcher MP, to refer Petition EN2662 under Standing Order 209(a) and (b). On 14 February 2022, the former Chair referred Petition 3731 to the former Minister under the same Standing Orders. As the former Minister did not provide a response before the dissolution of the 46th Parliament, I am now writing to do so.

Both petitions include proposals to restrict children's access to adult content online. Petition EN2662 calls for legislation to ban free-to-view adult content. Petition EN3731 calls for legislation to require international websites hosting adult material to require proof of age for access. The Australian Government understands the concerns raised in these petitions, and work is underway to protect Australian children from viewing adult content online.

The Government supports technological solutions to prevent children from accessing online pornography. In September 2019, the Social Policy and Legal Affairs Committee launched an inquiry into the effectiveness of age verification systems on pornographic and gambling websites. The Committee's final report, Protecting the Age of Innocence, was released on 5 March 2020. The Committee found that age verification would establish a significant barrier to protect young people and children from harmful online content, and made recommendations to support the implementation of age verification systems in Australia.

The eSafety Commissioner is now developing a roadmap for consideration in late 2022, which will advise on how to implement a proportionate, effective, and feasible age verification system in Australia to restrict children's access to online pornography. You can find more information about the roadmap at www.esafety.gov.au/about-us/consultation-cooperation/age-verification.

Under the Online Safety Act 2021 (the Act), the eSafety Commissioner has powers to request or require takedown of illegal and restricted online content. Most pornographic content will fall under the Commissioner's powers to respond to material that is, or is likely to be, classified as X18+ or R18+ material under the Online Content Scheme. This is 'class 2 material'. The eSafety Commissioner can respond to X 18+ material by issuing a removal notice to the service provider if the material is provided from Australia, and to R 18+ by requiring that the material provided from Australia can only be accessed by adults by placing the content behind a Restricted Access System.

Class 1 material is more serious material that is, or would likely be, refused classification (including child sexual exploitation material). The Commissioner has a stronger set of powers to requiring the removal of this material no matter where it is hosted.

Under the Act, industry is being expected to do more to keep its users safe, particularly children. The Act requires that online service providers develop updated industry codes to address online harms relating to class 1 and class 2 materials. The updated codes will place the onus on industry to give consumers the option of subscribing to a filtered internet service, and will require that industry provide families with technological solutions to help limit their access to harmful online content (including pornography). Work on industry codes is currently underway.

The Government, on behalf of the Australian community, has also developed the Online Safety (Basic Online Safety Expectations) Determination 2022 to articulate the proactive steps industry should take to address unlawful and harmful material and activity. Expectations include that service providers must take reasonable steps to ensure that technological or other measures are in effect to prevent access to adult materials (like pornography) by children.

Service providers are required to report to the eSafety Commissioner on what they are doing to meet their expectations. The eSafety Commissioner can report publicly on service providers that are not meeting the Australian community's expectations.
The eSafety Commissioner's website (www.esafety.gov.au) contains useful information on what Australians can do to keep their children safe online.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowlands
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition number EN3555, requesting to fast track the approval of the COVAX-19 vaccine in Australia. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government remains committed to providing access to free and effective COVID-19 vaccines to everyone living in Australia. The Government has invested in a diverse portfolio of COVID-19 vaccines that use a variety of technical platforms, securing supply for all eligible populations within Australia.

The safety of the Australian population has always been the highest priority of the Government. The Government is working closely with the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), which has responsibility for formally assessing the safety, quality, and efficacy of medicines, including vaccines, prior to their approval for use and inclusion in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG). This formal regulatory approval means that the vaccines can be lawfully supplied in Australia.

Due to the nature of the COVID-19 pandemic, all COVID-19 vaccines have been approved via the provisional approval pathway. Applications for provisional registration must include a comprehensive data package to support the medicine's safety, quality, and efficacy, as well as a source of product manufactured to pharmaceutical Good Manufacturing Practice requirements. Decisions on provisional registrations are also informed by expert advice from the Advisory Committee on Vaccines, an independent committee with expertise in scientific, medical, and clinical fields including consumer representation. Vaccines are provisionally approved only if the TGA's rigorous assessment process is completed, and the benefits of the vaccine are considered to be greater than any potential risks.

Even though the decision to provisionally approve these vaccines was made on the basis of short-term efficacy and safety data, the data submitted to support the quality, safety and efficacy of the COVID-19 vaccines showed a positive benefit-risk ratio. Waiting for data to establish the duration of protection would not have allowed these vaccines to have been available. The short-term efficacy of these vaccines has been proven, with the six-month protection period preventing many hospitalisations and death.

Continued approval is dependent upon the evidence of longer-term efficacy and safety from ongoing clinical trials and post-market assessment. As part of the provisional approval, sponsors are required to continue to submit longer-term evidence to the TGA. As this implies, these studies are continuing to gather data on longer-term safety and effectiveness to complement post-market monitoring and spontaneous adverse event data. It is anticipated that these will be completed between late 2021 and mid-2024, which, depending on the vaccine, may coincide with a sponsor's application to transition to full registration. Further information about this process can be found on the TGA website at www.tga.gov.au/covid-19-vaccine-approval-process.

Vaxine Pty Ltd, the company developing Flinders University's COVID-19 vaccine candidate "COVAX-19®" was funded $1 million through the Australian Government's Biomedical Translation Bridge Program, an initiative of the Medical Research Future Fund. Vaxine Pty Ltd has not yet submitted an application for provisional registration. However, a limited amount of preliminary clinical data was submitted to the TGA to support the provisional determination application.

On 15 December 2021 the TGA granted provisional determination to Vaxine Pty Ltd for their COViD-19 vaccine, SARS-CoV-2 rS (Vax-S-dTM-W1) (SPIKOGEN VACCINE), which is also known as COVAX-19.. Provisional Determination is the first step in the provisional registration process. Importantly, provisional determination does not mean that an application has or will be made, or that the vaccine will be provisionally approved for inclusion in the ARTG. Registration and supply in Australia will only commence should the vaccine be approved as safe and effective by the TGA. In May 2022, the provisional determination for this vaccine candidate was extended and will now lapse on 14 December 2022.

The TGA has not received an application from Vaxine Pty Ltd to provisionally register COVAX-19 for use in Australia. Therefore, this vaccine candidate cannot be evaluated or approved for use in Australia. To date, COVAX-19 has only received regulatory approval from the Iranian Food and Drug Administration for use in Iran. However, if the sponsor holds the appropriate evidence, they are welcome at any time to make an application to the TGA to register their vaccine in the ARTG. If an application for a COVID-19 vaccine is received, it will be treated with the greatest priority.

The TGA has not been provided with a copy of the submission made to the Iranian regulator. The Iranian regulator is not considered by OECD country regulators, nor the global peak group of regulators [the International Coalition of Medicines Regulatory Agencies (ICMRA)], as a 'comparable' regulator. Therefore, we have very little information on Iranian regulatory requirements for these products. However, in February 2022, the TGA's Deputy Secretary, Adjunct Professor Skerritt, wrote to the Iranian Ambassador in Canberra to outline the TGA's requirements should an application from Vaxine Pty Ltd be made. On 4 August 2022 Professor Skerritt also met with the Ambassador and discussed these requirements.

As explained above, to be registered in the ARTG, a sponsor must submit an application containing a comprehensive dossier to support the vaccine. The results of overseas clinical trials, such as those from the Phase Ill clinical trial undertaken by Vaxine Pty Ltd in collaboration with Iranian biotechnology company CinnaGen in Iran, can be used to support the sponsor's future application to the TGA. Details of the clinical trials underway for the COVAX-19 vaccine can be found on the COVID-19 vaccine tracker at www.covid19.trackvaccines.orgLvaccines/8/.

The Moderna (SPIKEVAX), Pfizer (COMIRNATY), AstraZeneca (VAXZEVRIA) and Novavax (NUVAXOVID) vaccines, which are currently available in Australia as part of the national rollout, have been provisionally registered by the TGA. Australians can have confidence that these vaccines have met the high safety, efficacy and quality standards required for use in Australia.

For individuals looking to be vaccinated with a more traditional, protein-based vaccine option, NUVAXOVID is now available for administration in Australia to those aged 18 years and older. Protein vaccines use a non-infectious component found on the surface of the coronavirus and are manufactured in cells in a laboratory. After vaccination, immune cells recognise the vaccine protein as foreign and launch an immune response against it. The vaccine was subject to the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval process, and the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI) has noted that NUVAXOVID is highly effective in preventing symptomatic COVID-19 in adults.

On 22 July 2022, the TGA granted provisional approval to extend the use of NUVAXOVID for use in individuals aged 12-17 years. The potential use of this vaccine in the national COVID-19 vaccination program in this age group is being considered by ATAGI who will provide advice to the Government in the coming weeks.

The Government has also finalised an agreement with global pharmaceutical company Moderna that secures the production of up to 100 million Australian made mRNA doses every year and in addition, provides hundreds of manufacturing jobs. The strategic partnership will ensure Australia can meet its ongoing COVID-19 vaccine needs, and any other new and innovative respiratory mRNA vaccines. It will also make Australia a critical regional hub for mRNA technology development and production, bolstering our local biotechnology sector.

It is important for Australians to have access to credible and timely information about COVID-19 vaccines. I strongly encourage everyone to stay up to date on all news and announcements, by regularly checking the Department's website at www.health.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler

COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence to the former Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Greg Hunt concerning petition number EN3587 requesting the implementation of a policy restricting financial benefits to vaccinated individuals. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public- health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death. Whilst COVID-19 vaccination is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia, everyone is encouraged to get vaccinated but still maintains the option to choose.

The advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation continues to be that vaccination against COVID-19 is the most effective way to reduce death and severe illness associated with COVID-19 infection.
Medicare is Australia's universal health insurance scheme. It guarantees all Australians (and some overseas visitors) access to a wide range of health and hospital services at low or no cost.

Eligibility for Medicare is defined in the Health Insurance Act 1973 available at:
.www.legislation.gov.au/Series/C2004A00101 and is generally limited to persons who reside in Australia and are either Australian citizens, New Zealand citizens, permanent residents or, in certain circumstances, applicants for permanent residence. Eligibility for Medicare is not dependant on a person's vaccination status.
Australians can access credible and timely information about COVID-19 vaccines, news and announcements on the Department of Health's website at: www.health.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence to the former Minister for Health and Aged Care concerning petition number EN3595 requesting assistance with funding and other support for the production of a new SARS-CoV-2 vaccine.

The Australian Government is committed to investing in health and medical research that makes a difference to the lives of Australians. To date the Government has invested $130 million from the Medical Research Future Fund (MRFF) to support research on vaccines and treatments for COVID-19, as well as further preparedness.

Of this, a total of $24.1 million has been made available for the development of nine vaccine candidates against COVID-19. This research will also support the advancement of new vaccine technology platforms to protect Australians from future pandemics.

Funding for research for the vaccine being developed by EngenelC, raised in the petition, is best progressed through peer-reviewed contestable processes to ensure the integrity of research design, quality, and safety for patients. There are two distinct, but complementary funds available to support health and medical research: the MRFF, which funds priority research; and the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC), focusing on investigator-led research.

Information on all open MRFF and NHMRC grant opportunities is available on the Government's GrantConnect website. I strongly encourage EngenelC or the petitioners to register with GrantConnect at www.grants.gov.au to ensure they do not miss out on any funding opportunities.

In addition, other Commonwealth support for medical research and medical innovation includes Research Block Grants to Universities, funding for research through the Australian Research Council, the Biomedical Translation Fund which supports the commercialisation of innovative biotechnology, the National Critical Research Infrastructure Strategy, and Cooperative Research Centres. Information on grant opportunities is also available on the Government's GrantConnect website.

I would also like to draw your attention to the Novavax COVID-19 vaccine which has been made available to Australians aged 18 and over since 21 February 2022. Novavax is a protein subunit vaccine. Protein vaccines use a non-infectious component found on the surface of the virus and are manufactured in cells in a laboratory. After vaccination, immune cells recognise the vaccine protein as foreign and launch an immune response against it.

This vaccine provides a further option to those who may have been hesitant to use the other available options. Further information is available on the Department of Health and Aged Care website at www.health.gov.au using the search term 'Novavax'.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Taxation
Dear Committee Secretary
I refer to Petition EN3614 concerning income statements being sent to myGov.

myGov is an online digital service run by Services Australia, on behalf of the Australian Government. It is not compulsory to have a myGov account. By having a myGov account, a user agrees to be bound by the terms of use. Services Australia is responsible for ensuring the security of personal information collected, stored, or passing through myGov and handling information in accordance with the privacy law. myGov is a secure way to access government services, including the Australian Taxation Office (ATO), in one place.

The ATO is authorised under the tax law to collect, hold, use and disclose a wide range of personal information to administer the taxation and superannuation laws. The tax secrecy laws generally prohibit tax officers from disclosing protected taxpayer information to third-parties. However, limited exceptions to this general prohibition exist that allow disclosure to certain entities for specific purposes (e.g. to a court or tribunal for the purpose of administering a taxation law). Exceptions are generally limited in scope and internal to Government.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones

COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence to the former Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Greg Hunt regarding petition number EN3623, requesting an investigation into COVID-19 vaccine side effects. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The safety of the Australian population has always been the highest priority of the Australian Government. That is why it is working closely with the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI) and all state and territory health departments to ensure that monitoring of COVID-19 vaccine safety is of the highest possible standard in Australia.

Australians can be assured that the TGA has comprehensively evaluated each of the provisionally registered COVID-19 vaccines available in Australia to ensure that they meet Australia's high standards of safety, quality, and efficacy.

The TGA has long-established processes, pathways, and data requirements for the evaluation of vaccines in Australia based on internationally recognised guidelines. A large team of technical and clinical experts at the TGA carefully review the data submitted by the sponsor, which includes clinical trial data conducted from thousands of participants, to ensure that strict safety and efficacy thresholds are met and seek expert advice from the Advisory Committee on Vaccines, an independent clinical expert committee, prior to a senior medical officer making a regulatory decision under the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989.

A vaccine is only provisionally approved by the TGA if this rigorous process is completed, and the benefits of the vaccine are considered to be much greater than any potential risks. As part of the provisional approval, sponsors are also required to continue to submit longer-term evidence to the TGA on efficacy, safety from ongoing clinical trials and post-market assessment.

The TGA has published a range of regulatory documents relating to the provisional approval of each COVID-19 vaccine, which provide detailed information about the evaluation process and the data that were considered. These include the Australian Public Assessment Report, the Product Information and the Consumer Medicine Information documents, which are available at www.tga.gov.au/covid-19-vaccines.

As with every vaccine or medication, there is a small risk that some people who have the COVID-19 vaccine may experience rare side effects. Vaccination adverse effects and safety are monitored by the TGA and AusVaxSafety, a Government funded active safety surveillance system that complements the work of the TGA.

Gathering adverse event reports is just the first step in determining whether a suspected side effect is related to the vaccine. The TGA has a well-established and effective system in place to detect and investigate potential new safety issues relating to vaccines. Many of these processes have been enhanced dramatically for COVID-19 vaccines, making this the most intense safety monitoring of therapeutic goods ever conducted in Australia.

The TGA works closely with other regulators around the world and shares information from vaccination programs with reliable adverse events data covering hundreds of millions of people and continually analysing the latest evidence regarding COVID-19 vaccines. With vaccination programs being rolled out across the globe, regulators have access to enormous amounts of real-world data from a variety of sources to add to what we have learned from the initial clinical trials and subsequent follow-up studies.

Should the TGA suspect there is a safety issue with a vaccine, they will immediately conduct a thorough investigation of the issue. If the TGA determines that a report of a significant adverse event may impact the benefit-risk balance for the vaccine, the report is referred to a Vaccine Safety Investigation Group. This is a panel of independent medical and vaccine experts who undertake a detailed causality assessment using a structed approach recommended by the World Health Organisation. If they determine that the safety concern is significant, they will respond appropriately, including communication to the Australian public through the TGA.

In-depth information on the TGA's safety monitoring role, the COVID-19 vaccine safety monitoring plan and weekly safety reports can be found on the TGA website at www.tga.gov.au using the search terms 'COVID-19 vaccine safety monitoring and reporting'. Survey results collected from over 6 million Australians can also be viewed on the AusVaxSafety website at www.ausvaxsafety.org.au/safety-data/covid-19-vaccines.

With these processes in place, the health advice from the TGA and the ATAGI remains that the protective benefits of COVID-19 vaccination far outweigh any potential risks. Vaccination against COVID-19 is still the most effective way to reduce deaths and severe illness associated with infection.

It is important for Australians to have access to credible and timely information about COVID-19 vaccines. Australians can learn more about the rollout on the Department of Health and Aged Care website at www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence to the former Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Greg Hunt concerning petition EN3659 on COVID-19 vaccination mandates. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.
At the same time, the Government's position on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia. Everyone maintains the option to choose.

The Government has made it mandatory for those working in residential aged care to receive a COVID-19 vaccination, which was advised by the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee and accepted by National Cabinet. This is enforced through state and territory public health orders, effective 17 September 2021.

As the COVID-19 pandemic is a public health emergency, states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public health, are managing the pandemic in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice.
